    Within a period of ten (10) days from the filing of an appeal the electrical board of adjustments and appeals shall hear the appeal, together with the testimony of all parties concerned, and render a decision thereon within three (3) days thereafter. 
(Ord. No. O-11F-79, § 9, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-255. - Scope of decision on appeal. 
(a)  The electrical board of adjustments and appeals when appealed to and after a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of the electrical code adopted by section 5-131 to any particular case when, in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice, and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of the code or the public interest, or when in its opinion the interpretation of the electrical inspector should be modified or reversed. 
(b)  A decision of the electrical board of adjustments and appeals to vary the application of any provision of the electrical code adopted by section 5-131 or to modify an order of the electrical inspector shall specify in what manner the variation or modification is made, the conditions upon which it is made and the reasons therefor. 
(c)  If a decision of the electrical board of adjustments and appeals reverses or modifies a refusal, order, or disallowance of the electrical inspector, or varies the application of any provisions of the code adopted by section 5-131, the electrical inspector shall immediately take action in accordance with the decision. 
(Ord. No. O-11F-79, § 9, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-256. - Appeal of decision of board to city council. 
    Any person aggrieved by a decision of the electrical board of adjustments and appeals shall have the right of appeal to the city council within ten (10) days from the rendition of the decision by the board. The appeal shall be perfected by written notice addressed to the mayor and city council asking for a hearing by the city council, and the action of the city council thereon shall be final, except that due process shall not be denied and further appeal may be made to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. O-11F-79, § 9, 11-19-79) 
Secs. 5-257-5-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Water, § 19-21 et seq.; sewers, § 19-56 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-271. - Plumbing code adopted; penalty for violation thereof; designated officials. 
(a)  The International Plumbing Code, as now written and hereinafter amended, is hereby adopted by the City of Crockett, Texas, and the provisions thereof are incorporated herein as fully as if set out at length herein. The provisions thereof shall be controlling within the city for all matters set forth therein. At least three (3) copies of the current version of the International Plumbing Code are now filed in the office of the city secretary, and as the International Plumbing Code is, from time to time, amended, at least three (3) copies of the International Plumbing Code and amendments shall be and remain filed in the office of the city secretary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the plumbing code adopted by subsection (a). 
(c)  Within the code, when reference is made to the duties of certain officials named therein, the designated official of the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in the code shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provision of the code are concerned. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 1, 11-19-79; Ord. No. O-5B-88, §§ 1, 4, 5-19-88; Ord. No. O-5-97, § VI, 5-19-97; Ord. No. O-02-13, § III, 2-4-13) 
Editor's note- Section 4 of Ord. No. O-5B-88, adopted May 19, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code, hence its inclusion as § 5-271(c) was at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Adoption of other technical codes: mechanical, § 5-1; building, § 5-16; housing, § 5-76; electrical, § 5-131; gas, § 5-356; fire prevention, § 7-16; application of plumbing code to substandard buildings, § 5-426. 
Sec. 5-271.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-5-97, § VII, adopted May 19, 1997, repealed former § 5-271.1 of the Code, which pertained to amendments to the plumbing code and derived from Ord. No. O-5B-88, §§ 2, 3, adopted May 19, 1988. 
Sec. 5-272. - Street openings. 
(a)  All openings made in the public streets or alleys to install plumbing must be made as carefully as possible and all materials excavated from the trenches shall be removed or placed where the least inconvenience to the public will be caused. 
(b)  All openings must be replaced in precisely the same condition as before the excavation started and all rubbish and materials must be removed at once, leaving the street or sidewalks clean and in perfect repair. 
(c)  All openings shall be marked with sufficient barriers. Flares or red lamps shall be maintained around the opening at night and all other precautions shall be taken by the plumber or excavator to protect the public from damage to person or property. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 9, 11-19-79) 
Secs. 5-273-5-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLUMBING INSPECTOR 

Sec. 5-286. - Office created; appointment; qualifications; compensation; assistants. 
    There is hereby created the office of plumbing inspector who shall be appointed by the city administrator, subject to approval of the city council. The plumbing inspector shall be of good moral character, versed in the approved methods of plumbing installations and shall not be directly or indirectly engaged in the business of plumbing or plumbing supplies. He shall receive such compensation as the city council may decide. He may appoint assistants when authorized to do so by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-287. - General duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall prepare or cause to be prepared suitable forms for applications, permits, inspection reports and such other requirements of his office which require forms. 
(c)  The plumbing inspector shall issue permits and collect fees. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector to inspect and test all plumbing work for compliance with this article and the plumbing code adopted by section 5-271, and to enforce the changing of installations that do not meet the requirements thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 3, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-288. - Right of entry. 
    The plumbing inspector is granted the authority to enter all buildings within or without the corporate limits of the city, when such buildings are connected, or are to be connected to the municipal water or sewage system. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 3, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-289. - Duties and authority regarding impure and unpotable water. 
(a)  The plumbing inspector and the city water department are authorized and directed to determine all potential hazards to the purity or potability of the city water supply. Upon determining said potential hazards it shall be their duty to immediately cause notice to be sent to the owner or such other person responsible for the premises, specifying the hazards, and notifying the person that in the event that the hazard is not corrected within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice, all water services shall be discontinued until the requirements of this article have been complied with. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector or the city water department are authorized to discontinue or cause to be discontinued all water service or services to any and all premises, lands, buildings or structures where it is found that an immediate hazard exists to the purity or potability of the city water supply. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 3, 11-19-79) 
Secs. 5-290-5-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 5-301. - Required. 
    No plumbing installation or alteration shall be made within the city or outside the city if connection to the city water or sewage system is to be made without first obtaining a written permit therefor from the plumbing inspector or other designated official. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 4, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-302. - Persons entitled to permit. 
    Only those persons authorized by the plumbing appeals and advisory board may apply for the permits required by this division; however, a permit may be issued to a homeowner to install or alter plumbing in a single-family residence, provided the homeowner does the work himself and that the building is owned and occupied or to be occupied by the owner as his home. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 4, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-303. - Application. 
    Application for a permit required by this division shall be made in writing and must be presented in person during normal inspection department hours and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The date; 
(2)  The name of the property owner; 
(3)  The name of the applicant; 
(4)  The address or location where the work is to be done; 
(5)  A description of the work to be done; and 
(6)  Any other information deemed necessary by the plumbing inspector. 
(Ord. No. O-6B-82, § 4, 6-7-82) 
Sec. 5-304. - Fee. 
    The charge for the issuance of plumbing permits shall be as follows: 
Type of permit      Fee 
(1)  Field lines (moving and hookup) ..... $50.00 
(2)  Remodeling and additions (per inspection) ..... $50.00 
(3)  Complete house or new building (per inspection) ..... $50.00 
(4)  Commercial (per inspection) ..... $70.00 
(5)  Sprinkler system for a building for fire protection ..... $50.00 
(6)  Lawn sprinkler system ..... $50.00 
(Ord. No. O-6B-82, § 1, 6-7-82; Ord. No. O-10-02, § II, 10-7-02; Ord. No. O-03-14, § II, 3-17-14) 
Secs. 5-305-5-315. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PLUMBING BOARD 

Sec. 5-316. - Created; membership. 
    There is hereby created a six-member plumbing appeals and advisory board consisting of: 
(1)  A licensed master plumber. 
(2)  A licensed journeyman plumber. 
(3)  A building contractor. 
(4)  The city engineer. 
(5)  The city health officer. 
(6)  A licensed architect, registered engineer or alternate selection. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 5, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-317. - Alternate member. 
    If a licensed architect or registered engineer is not available for membership to the plumbing appeals and advisory board, the mayor may appoint a lay person he deems qualified to serve as a representative of the general public. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 5, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-318. - Eligibility of city engineer and health officer. 
    The city engineer and the city health officer shall be eligible to serve on the plumbing appeals and advisory board only as long as they hold office. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 5, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-319. - Ex officio member. 
    The plumbing inspector shall be an ex officio, nonvoting member of the plumbing appeals and advisory board. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 5, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-320. - Appointment and terms of office. 
    Members of the plumbing appeals and advisory board and their successors, except for the city engineers and the city health officer, shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council and shall hold office for terms of four (4) years, or until their successors are appointed and have qualified; however, of the initial members of the board, two (2) members shall serve terms of two (2) years and two (2) for four (4) years as determined by the mayor in making the appointments. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 5, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-321. - Compensation. 
    All members of the plumbing appeals and advisory board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 5, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-322. - Election of officers and adoption of rules. 
    The members of the plumbing appeals and advisory board shall meet as soon after their appointment as practicable for the purpose of organization. The board shall formally elect a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary from its members and may adopt such rules as it deems necessary for the orderly conduct of its affairs. A full and complete record of the proceedings of the board shall be kept. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 5, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-323. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members of the plumbing appeals and advisory board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 6, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-324. - Right of appeal to board. 
    Any person aggrieved by any interpretation of this article or by any decision or ruling by the plumbing inspector under this article shall have the right to make an appeal to the plumbing appeals and advisory board. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 6, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-325. - Hearing on appeal. 
    Within ten (10) days from the filing of an appeal the plumbing appeals and advisory board shall hear the appeal, together with the testimony of all parties concerned, and render a decision within three (3) days of the hearing. In hearing such an appeal, the board shall not have the power to waive or set aside the requirements of this article, but shall have the power to interpret its provisions and in case of alternate types of installation or material, shall determine whether or not such alternate type of installation or material is, in fact, equal to the standards of this article, considering adequacy, stability, strength, sanitation and safety to the public health and welfare. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 6, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-326. - Appeals from board. 
    Any person who may be aggrieved by a decision of the plumbing appeals and advisory board shall have a right of appeal to the city council within ten (10) days from the rendition of such decision. The appeal shall be perfected by written notice addressed to the mayor and city council asking for a hearing by the city council, and the action of the city council thereon shall be final, except that due process shall not be denied and further appeal may be made to the nearest court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 6, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-327. - New methods and materials passed on by board. 
    All requests for use of materials or methods not covered in this article or the plumbing code adopted by section 5-271 shall be fully supported by factual evidence, or prior approval, from a recognized testing agency or such impartial qualified authority acceptable to the plumbing appeals and advisory board. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 6, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-328. - Advisory responsibility of the board. 
    The plumbing advisory and appeals board shall submit to the city council such recommendations for the improvement and revision of this article and the plumbing code adopted by section 5-271 as it may from time to time deem necessary and proper in light of the development of new materials, methods or techniques which would result in a better and more economical installation. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 6, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-329. - Establishment of rules by board. 
    The plumbing advisory and appeals board shall establish and prepare in writing, and the plumbing inspector shall keep a copy of, requirements which must be met by each applicant desiring to obtain a plumber's license. The written requirements shall include a procedure for administering examinations and shall set forth each instance, if any, where the taking and passing of an examination is not required. The board shall be satisfied as to the qualification of each applicant prior to authorizing the issuance of a license to the applicant. The board shall be satisfied as to the qualification of each applicant prior to authorizing the issuance of a license to the applicant. The board shall also establish rules for license renewals. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 6, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-330. - Duty to prepare fee schedules. 
    The plumbing advisory and appeals board shall establish and prepare a written list of fees including fees for examinations, licenses, permits, inspections and for such other purposes deemed necessary by the board. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 6, 11-19-79) 
Secs. 5-331-5-340. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LICENSES 

Sec. 5-341. - Required; general prerequisites. 
    Every person desiring to work as a plumber within the city shall obtain a license to do so from the plumbing inspector. The license shall be of the type and upon the terms authorized by the plumbing appeals and advisory board. The plumbing inspector shall not issue a license to any applicant until authorized to do so by the board. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 7, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-342. - Bond required. 
    Every master plumber doing business in the city shall execute and deliver to the city a bond with a surety bonding company in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to indemnify the city or any citizen for any damage caused by the failure of such master plumber to comply strictly with the provisions of this article. No plumbing permit shall be issued to any master plumber unless this bond has been delivered to the city and is in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. O-11E-79, § 8, 11-19-79) 
Secs. 5-343-5-355. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GAS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Tax on sale of gas, § 18-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-356. - Gas code adopted; penalty for violation thereof. 
(a)  The International Gas Code, as now written and hereinafter amended, is hereby adopted by the City of Crockett, Texas, and the provisions thereof are incorporated herein as fully as if set out at length herein. The provisions thereof shall be controlling within the city for all matters set forth therein. At least three (3) copies of the current version of the International Gas Code are now filed in the office of the city secretary, and as the International Gas Code is, from time to time, amended, at least three (3) copies of the International Gas Code and amendments shall be and remain filed in the office of the city secretary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of the gas code adopted by subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 1, 11-19-79; Ord. No. O-5-97, § VIII, 5-19-97; Ord. No. O-02-13, § IV, 2-4-13) 
Cross reference- Adoption of other technical codes; mechanical, § 5-1; building, § 5-16; housing, § 5-76; electrical, § 5-131; plumbing, § 5-271; fire prevention, § 7-16. 
Secs. 5-357-5-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF ADJUSTMENTS AND APPEALS 

Sec. 5-371. - Created; appointments. 
    There is hereby appointed a board of adjustments and appeals, which shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-372. - Absence from meetings. 
    Continued absence of any member of the board of adjustments and appeals from regular meetings of the board shall, at the discretion of the city council, render such member liable to immediate removal from office. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-373. - Terms; vacancies. 
    Of the members first appointed to the board of adjustments and appeals, two (2) shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year, two (2) for a term of two (2) years, one (1) for a term of three (3) years, and thereafter they shall be appointed for terms of four (4) years. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the manner of which original appointments are required to be made. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-374. - Quorum; voting. 
    Three (3) members of the board of adjustments and appeals shall constitute a quorum. In varying the application of any provisions of this article or the gas code adopted by section 5-271, or in modifying an order of the gas inspector, the affirmative votes of the majority present, but not less than three (3) affirmative votes shall be required. A board member shall not act in a case in which he has a personal interest. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-375. - Secretary to board; records. 
    The gas inspector shall act as secretary of the board of adjustments and appeals and shall make a detailed record of all its proceedings, which shall set forth the reasons for its decisions, the vote of each member participating therein, the absence of a member, and any failure of a member to vote. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-376. - Adoption of rules; meetings. 
    The board of adjustments and appeals shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of the gas code adopted by section 5-356 or this article. The board shall meet at regular intervals, to be determined by the chairman, or in any event, the board shall meet within ten (10) days after a notice of appeal has been received. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Secs. 5-377-5-387. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - APPEALS 

Sec. 5-388. - Right to appeal. 
    Whenever the gas inspector shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of installation proposed to be followed, or materials to be used in a building or structure, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the code adopted by section 5-356 or this article do not apply, or that an equally good or more desirable material or method of installation can be employed in any specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of the gas code adopted by section 5-356 or any of the regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the owner of such building or structure, or his duly authorized agent, may appeal from the decision of the gas inspector to the board of adjustments and appeals. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-389. - Notice of appeal; fee. 
    A notice of appeal filed pursuant to this division shall be in writing and filed within ninety (90) days after the decision is rendered by the gas inspector. A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall accompany the notice of appeal. Appeals hereunder shall be on forms provided by the gas inspector. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-390. - When time for appeal may be limited. 
    If a building or structure, due to the condition of the gas piping, appliances and other apparatus is unsafe or dangerous, in the opinion of the gas inspector, he may, in his order, limit the time for such appeal to a shorter period. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-391. - Decisions of board generally. 
(a)  Every decision of the board of adjustments and appeals shall be final, subject, however, to such remedy as any aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. The decision shall be in writing and shall indicate the vote upon the decision. The decision shall be promptly filed in the office of the gas inspector and shall be open to public inspection. A certified copy of the decision shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant and a copy shall be kept publicly posted in the office of the gas inspector for two (2) weeks after the filing. 
(b)  The board of adjustments and appeals shall, in every case, reach a decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. 
(c)  If a decision of the board of adjustments and appeals reverses or modifies a refusal, order or disallowance of the gas inspector or varies the application of any provision of the gas code adopted by section 5-356, the gas inspector shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-392. - Ruling on variances in application of gas code. 
(a)  The board of adjustments and appeals, when so appealed to and after a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of the gas code adopted by section 5-356 to any particular case when, in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice, and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of the code or the public interest, or when, in its opinion the interpretation of the gas inspector should be modified or reversed. 
(b)  A decision of the board of adjustments and appeals to vary the application of any provision of the gas code adopted by section 5-356 or to modify an order of the gas inspector shall specify in what manner such variation or modification is to be made and the conditions upon which it is to be made and the reasons therefor. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 2, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-393. - Permit fees. 
    The fees for permits required by the gas code adopted by section 5-356 shall be as follows: 
Type of permit      Fee 
(1)  Field lines (moving and hookup) ..... $50.00 
(2)  New building ..... $50.00 
(3)  Commercial ..... $70.00 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 3, 11-19-79; Ord. No. O-10-02, § III, 10-7-02; Ord. No. O-03-14, § III, 3-17-14) 
Secs. 5-394-4-405. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - GAS FITTERS 

Sec. 5-406. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the occupation of the installation, extension or alteration of consumer's gas piping or gas appliances without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 4, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-407. - Bond. 
    No license shall be issued pursuant to this division until the applicant shall have executed and delivered a good and sufficient bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), with a corporate surety, conditioned for the faithful performance of all work entered upon or contracted for, in strict accordance and compliance with the provisions of this article and the gas code adopted by section 5-356. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 4, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-408. - License fee. 
    The fee for a license required by this article shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year, which shall be paid into the city treasury before the license shall become effective. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 4, 11-19-79) 
Sec. 5-409. - Exemption for homeowners. 
    Nothing contained in this division shall be construed as prohibiting an individual from installing or repairing his own appliances or installing, extending, replacing, altering or repairing consumer's piping on his own premises, or as requiring a license or a bond from an individual doing such work on his own premises; however, all such work shall be done in conformity with all other provisions of the gas code adopted by section 5-356. 
(Ord. No. O-11B-79, § 4, 11-19-79) 
Secs. 5-410-5-425. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SUBSTANDARD BUILDINGS AND PREMISES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-9C-85, §§ 1, 2, adopted Sept. 16, 1985, repealed Art. VII, §§ 5-426-5-435, and enacted a new Art. VII to read as herein set forth. Prior to repeal, Art. VII pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Ord. No. O-7-79, §§ 1, 3-9, 12, adopted July 2, 1974, and Ord. No. O-7-85, § 1, adopted July 1, 1985. 
Charter reference- Condemnation of structures, § 11.08. 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, § 11-16 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority of city regarding dilapidated structures, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1015n. 

Sec. 5-426. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  Substandard buildings or premises shall mean buildings, structures or premises which are a hazard to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens and shall include all buildings, structures or premises conducive to the harboring of rats or mice or other disease-carrying animals or insects reasonably calculated to spread disease and shall include: 
(1)  All buildings or structures which do not have the number of commodes, water closets, urinals and lavatories required by the plumbing code adopted by section 5-271, or which have pit privies where the same are not permitted by law, or which are not connected to the city sewer when required by law, or where inadequate and insanitary pit privies or septic tanks are maintained. 
(2)  All buildings or structures that have become deteriorated through natural causes or by damage through exposure to the elements, especially wind, hail or rain or damage through fire to the extent that the roof, windows and doors, or portions of the house, building or structure which protect it from the weather, will no longer reasonably protect it from the weather. 
(3)  All buildings or structures which constitute, or in which are maintained, fire hazards, as that term is defined through the fire prevention code adopted by section 7-16. 
(4)  All buildings or structures which are so structurally deteriorated that they are in danger of collapse, or which cannot be expected to withstand reasonably anticipated storms or tornadoes. 
(5)  All buildings or structures not wired in conformity with the electrical code adopted by section 5-131. 
(6)  All buildings or structures not constructed in conformity with the building code adopted by section 5-16. 
(7)  All buildings and structures and premises surrounding buildings and structures, including vacant lots, whereon there exist accumulations of refuse, vegetation or other matter that creates breeding and living places for insects and rodents. 
(b)  Premises shall mean all areas surrounding buildings and structures as well as vacant lots. 
(Ord. No. O-9C-85, § 2, 9-16-85; Ord. No. O-7-91, § I, 7-22-91) 
Sec. 5-427. - Building and standards commission. 
(a)  There is hereby created a building and standards commission to hear and determine cases concerning alleged violations of ordinances of the City of Crockett. 
(b)  The building and standards commission shall consist of one (1), five-member panel, all of whom must be residents of the city and are to be appointed for terms of two (2) years each. Members of the building and standards commission shall be nominated by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. 
(c)  The city council may remove a commission member for cause on a written charge. Before a decision regarding removal is made, the city council must hold a public hearing on the matter if requested by the commission member subject to the removal action. 
(d)  A vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term. 
(e)  Eight (8) alternate members of the commission may be appointed, who shall serve in the absence of one (1) or more regular members when requested to do so by the mayor or city administrator. The alternate members serve for the same period and are subject to removal in the same manner as the regular members. A vacancy in the alternate members is filled in the same manner as a vacancy among the regular members. 
(f)  Four (4) members of the building and standards commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and the concurring vote of four (4) members of the building and standards commission is necessary to take any action. All cases before the building and standards commission shall be presented by the code enforcement officer. 
(g)  Meetings of the commission shall be held at the call of the chairman of the commission and at such other times as determined by a quorum of the commission. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public. The chairman, or in the chairman's absence, the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. 
(h)  The commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member on each question or the fact that a member is absent or fails to vote. The commission shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions. The minutes and records shall be filed immediately in the office of the commission as public records. 
(i)  A majority of the commission shall adopt rules for the entire commission, in accordance with the provisions of the Crockett Code. The rules shall establish procedures for use in hearings, providing ample opportunity for presentation of evidence and testimony by respondents or persons opposing charges brought by the city or its code enforcement officer relating to alleged violations of ordinances. 
(Ord. No. O-9C-85, § 2, 9-16-85; Ord. No. O-10-01, § I, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 5-427.1. - Notice of proceedings before the building and standards commission. 
    Notice of all proceedings before the building and standards commission must be given: 
(1)  By personal delivery or by certified mail, return receipt requested and first class mail, to the record owners of the affected property and each holder of a recorded lien against the affected property, as shown by deed records and assumed name records of the County Clerk of Houston County, Texas, the records of the Houston County Appraisal District, the records of the Texas Secretary of State and the city tax and utility records. Notice must be given to a lienholder only if the address of the lienholder can be ascertained from the deed of trust establishing the lien or other applicable instruments on file in the office of the county clerk. The notice must contain the information set forth in subsection 5-427.1(5). 
(2)  To all unknown owners, by posting a copy of the notice on the front door of each improvement situated on the affected property or as close to the front door as practicable. 
(3)  The notice shall be mailed and posted on or before the tenth day before the date of the hearing before the commission and must state the date, time and place of the hearing. In addition, the notice must be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality on one (1) occasion on or before the tenth day before the date fixed for the hearing. 
(4)  The notice must contain the street address and legal description of the affected property, a statement that the structure is substandard, a brief and concise description of the substandard conditions, a brief description of the public hearing and the action recommended. 
(5)  The commission may file notice of a proceeding before the commission in the Official Public Records of Real Property in Houston County, Texas. The notice must contain the name and address of the owner of the affected property if that information can be determined from a reasonable search under subsection 5-427.1(1), a legal description of the affected property, and a description of the proceeding. The filing of the notice is binding on subsequent grantees, lienholders, mortgagees or other transferees of an interest in the property who acquire such interest after the filing of the notice and constitutes notice of the proceeding on any subsequent recipient of any interest in the property who acquires such interest after the filing of the notice. 
(6)  A copy of the final decision of the commission panel is to be personally delivered or sent by certified mail, return receipt requested and first class mail to all persons to whom notice is required to be sent under this section. The commission shall mail that copy promptly after the decision becomes final. In addition, an abbreviated copy of the order shall be published one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality within ten (10) calendar days after the date of the mailing of the copy. The order shall state the street address and legal description of the property, the date of the hearing, a brief statement indicating the results of the order, and instructions stating where a complete copy of the order may be obtained. A copy shall be filed in the office of the city secretary within ten (10) days of its issuance. 
(Ord. No. O-10-01, § II, 10-1-01; Ord. No. O-09E-12, § I, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 5-428. - Standards for repair, vacation or demolition. 
    The following standards may be followed in substance by the building and standards commission in ordering repair, vacation or demolition: 
(1)  If the building, structure or premises can reasonably be repaired so that it will not longer be in a condition which is in violation of the terms of this article it shall be ordered repaired. 
(2)  If the building, structure or premises is in such condition that it cannot be reasonably repaired or conformed to the codes referred to in section 5-426, then it shall be demolished. In any case, where a substandard building, structure or premises is fifty (50) percent damaged or decayed, it shall be demolished, and in all cases where a building cannot be repaired so that its existence will no longer be in violation of the terms of this article, it shall be demolished. 
(Ord. No. O-9C-85, § 2, 9-16-85) 
Sec. 5-429. - Substandard buildings. 
(a)  Order to show cause. Where an emergency does not exist and it shall come to the notice of the building and standards commission that a building, structure or premise is substandard, the commission may order the owner of the building, structure or premises, or the owner's authorized agent or representative, to appear and show cause why it should not be declared to be a substandard building, structure or premises and why the owner should not be ordered to vacate, repair, clean up, or destroy the building, structure or premises or relocate the occupants of the structure. The measures necessary to eliminate the building, structure or premises' substandard qualities shall be stated in the order. The date of the public hearing on the order shall not be less than ten (10) days after the order shall have been served. 
(b)  Hearing; order. On the date set in the notice of hearing, the hearing shall commence. On the basis of the hearing, the building and standards commission shall determine whether or not the building, structure or premise is a substandard building, structure or premises. If it is determined that a substandard building, structure or premises exists, the building and standards commission shall issue an order to the owner to take measures which are reasonably necessary to eliminate the building, structure or premises' substandard qualities. The commission may: 
(1)  Order the repair, demolition and removal, within a fixed period, of buildings found to be in violation of any ordinance; 
(2)  Declare a building substandard in accordance with the powers granted by this article; 
(3)  Order, in an appropriate case, the immediate removal of persons or property found on private property, enter on private property to secure the removal if it is determined that conditions exist on the property that constitute a violation of any ordinance, and order action to be taken as necessary to remedy, alleviate, or remove any substandard building found to exist; 
(4)  Issue orders or directives to any peace officer of the state, including a sheriff or constable or the chief of police of the municipality, to enforce and carry out the lawful orders or directives of the commission panel; 
(5)  Determine the amount and duration of the civil penalty the municipality may recover as provided by section 5-435 of the Crockett Code; 
(6)  Order that the structure be secured by the owner or lienholder from unauthorized entry within thirty (30) days. 
(c)  The order to repair or demolish and remove a substandard structure must require that the repair or removal and demolition be completed within thirty (30) days, unless the owner or lienholder establishes at the hearing that the work cannot be reasonably performed within thirty (30) days. In such event, the order shall provide specific time schedules for commencement and completion of the work. The order may not allow more than ninety (90) days to complete the work unless the owner or lienholder submits a detailed plan and time schedule for completion of the work, establishes that the scope and complexity of the work requires more than ninety (90) days, and submits regular progress reports to the code enforcement officer demonstrating compliance with the order. 
    The order shall specify a reasonable time to comply with the orders of the commission and shall provide specific time schedules for commencement and completion. 
(d)  The lien granted by this chapter is a privileged lien subordinate only to tax liens and all previously recorded bona fide mortgage liens attached to the real property to which the city's lien attaches. 
(e)  To enforce any civil penalty, the city secretary must file with the District Clerk of Houston County, Texas a certified copy of the order of the commission panel establishing the amount and duration of the penalty. No other proof is required for a district court to enter final judgment on the penalty. 
(Ord. No. O-9C-85, § 2, 9-16-85; Ord. No. O-7-91, § II, 7-22-91; Ord. No. O-10-01, § III, 10-1-01; Ord. No. O-09E-12, § II, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 5-429.1. - Additional authority regarding substandard buildings. 
(a)  In addition to the authority granted to the city by section 5-429, after the expiration of the time allotted under subsections (b) or (c) of section 5-429, for the repair, removal or demolition of a building, the city may: 
(1)  Demolish and remove the building at the expense of the city and assess the expenses on the land on which the building stands or to which it is attached; and 
(2)  Assess a civil penalty against the property owner for failure to repair, remove or demolish the building. 
(b)  The city may repair a building under subsection (a) only to the extent necessary to bring the building into compliance with the minimum standards and only if the building is a residential building with ten (10) or fewer dwelling units. The repairs may not improve the building to the extent that the building exceeds minimum housing standards. 
(c)  The city shall impose a lien against the land on which the building stands or stood, unless it is a homestead as protected by the Texas Constitution, to secure the payment of the repair, removal, or demolition expenses or the civil penalty. Promptly after the imposition of the lien, the city must file for record, in recordable form in the office of the County Clerk of Houston County, Texas, a written notice of the imposition of the lien. The notice must contain a legal description of the land. 
(d)  Except as provided by section 5-429, the city's lien to secure the payment of a civil penalty or the costs of repairs, removal, or demolition is inferior to any previously recorded bona fide mortgage lien attached to the real property to which the city's lien attaches if the mortgage lien was filed for record in the office of the County Clerk of Houston County, Texas before the date the civil penalty is assessed or the repair, removal, or demolition is begun by the city. The city's lien is superior to all other previously recorded judgment liens. 
(e)  Any civil penalty or other assessment imposed under this section accrues interest at the rate of ten (10) percent a year from the date of the assessment until paid in full. 
(f)  The city's right to the assessment lien may not be transferred to third parties. 
(g)  In any judicial proceeding regarding enforcement of municipal rights under this section, the prevailing party is entitled to recover reasonable attorney's fees from the nonprevailing party. 
(h)  A lien acquired under this section by the city for repair expenses may not be foreclosed if the property on which the repairs were made is occupied as a residential homestead by a person sixty-five (65) years of age or older. 
(Ord. No. O-7-91, § III, 7-22-91; Ord. No. O-09E-12, § III, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 5-430. - Emergency procedure. 
(a)  Substandard buildings or structures may be ordered to be, and shall be vacated, repaired or demolished when it shall appear that the building, structure or premise or the manner of its use constitutes an immediate and serious danger to life or property. The condition described in this section shall be deemed a condition justifying the use of emergency measures, and the building and standards commission may order any of the following emergency measures to be taken: 
(1)  The immediate vacation of the buildings, structure or adjoining structures. 
(2)  The vacation of the danger area around the building or structures. 
(3)  Such emergency shoring up and bracing of walls, roofs and supports as are required to render the buildings or structures safe. 
(4)  The destruction of such walls, roofs and supports or the entire structure or so much thereof as cannot be braced or made safely secure. 
(5)  The cleaning up of the premises and the removal of weeds, growth, trash, deteriorated equipment and personal property of no reasonable value. 
(b)  Posting. When any of the orders described in subsection (a) are given, notices shall be posted on or near the building or structure, notifying the public of the order and ordering all persons to keep out of the building or structure and the areas of danger surrounding it. 
(c)  Notice to property owner. When any of the orders described in subsection (a) are given, notice of the order shall be given as follows: 
(1)  The order shall be directed to the owner of the substandard building, structure or premises, or the owner's authorized representative, if known. 
(2)  Where notification can be accomplished without increasing the danger to life or property, notice shall be given by personal service on the owner of the building, structure or premises, or the owner's representative. In the event that such notification would create a delay which would materially increase danger to life or property, a reasonable effort to notify the owner shall be deemed sufficient. 
(d)  Execution of order. If the notification set forth in subsection (c) notice is given and the owner or the owner's representative refuses or fails to carry out the orders of the building and standards commission or fails to carry out the order satisfactorily, the building and standards commission may proceed to carry out the order either by private contract or through an agency of the city. The cost incurred shall constitute a valid lien against the property. The lien shall be extinguished if the property owner reimburses the city for the costs incurred. The lien may be enforced in the manner provided by this article. 
(Ord. No. O-9C-85, § 2, 9-16-85; Ord. No. O-7-91, § IV, 7-22-91) 
Sec. 5-431. - Owner's voluntary consent to demolition or cleanup. 
    The owner of a substandard building, structure or premises may enter into and execute an agreement to demolish, remedy or abate the same. In the event of a voluntary agreement, the necessity for notice and hearing shall not be required. The agreement may provide for the demolition, cleanup or other action to be at the owner's expense or the building and standards commission may, with the approval of the city council, authorize the expenditure of public funds to pay for all or an agreed portion of the costs of the demolition, cleanup or other work, subject to the availability and appropriation of funds for such purpose by the city. 
(Ord. No. O-9C-85, § 2, 9-16-85) 
Sec. 5-432. - Disclaimer of liability. 
    Neither the city, nor any authorized agent acting under the terms of this article shall be liable or have any liability by reason of orders issued or work done in compliance with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-9C-85, § 2, 9-16-85) 
Sec. 5-433. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section V of Ord. No. O-7-91, adopted July 22, 1991, repealed § 5-433 in its entirety. Formerly, § 5-433 pertained to lien and derived from § 2 of Ord. No. O-9C-85, adopted Sep. 16, 1985. 
Sec. 5-434. - Waiver of demolition permit fee. 
    The normal fee for a permit for demolition of a building or structure shall be waived when the demolition is performed under orders of the building and standards commission or city council or under an agreement between the property owner and the city as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. O-9C-85, § 2, 9-16-85) 
Sec. 5-435. - Civil penalties, injunctive relief, actions for removal of buildings and foreclosure of liens. 
(a)  Upon violation of any portion of article VII of chapter 5 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Crockett, Texas, entitled "Substandard Buildings and Premises," or of any order or regulation of the building and standards commission or city promulgated thereunder, the city may recover from the owner or the owner's representative with control over the premises a civil penalty in an amount not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each day of violation, beginning on the day after the date the defendant received notice of the provisions of article VII, if the defendant was actually notified of the provisions of the article and of the requirements needed to comply with the order or regulation. The amount of the civil penalty shall be set by the building and standards commission at the hearing provided for in section 5-429. 
(b)  In addition, or as an alternative thereto, the city may, in the event of such violation, obtain injunctive relief, as provided by state law. 
(c)  In addition, or as an alternative to the preceding portions of this section, the city may, in the event of such violation, bring an action to compel the repair or demolition of a building or structure or to obtain approval to remove the structure and recover removal costs. 
(d)  The civil penalty may be collected in a civil action in the appropriate court with jurisdiction in Houston County, Texas. 
(e)  All liens and assessments imposed under this article may be foreclosed in an action in the appropriate court with jurisdiction in Houston County, Texas. 
(Ord. No. O-7-91, § VI, 7-22-91; Ord. No. O-09E-12, § IV, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 5-436. - Appeal to the district court. 
(a)  Any owner or lienholder may appeal any order of the building and standards commission to the District Court of Houston County, Texas within thirty (30) days after a copy of the order of the building and standards commission is mailed or personally delivered, by filing a verified petition stating that the decision is illegal in whole or in part. Review by the district court is de novo, and the district court may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the building and standards commission. 
(b)  The order of the building and standards commission is abated during the pendency of the appeal to the district court. 
(Ord. No. O-09E-12, § V, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 5-437. - Administrative search warrant. 
    The code enforcement officer, fire marshal or city health officer may apply to a District Judge of Houston County, Texas for an administrative search warrant to be issued to discover violations of this article. The search warrant may be issued only upon an affidavit stating probable cause. 
(Ord. No. O-09E-12, § VI, 9-4-12) 
Secs. 5-438-5-500. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HOUSE MOVING FEE 

Sec. 5-501. - Fee. 
    The fee for moving a house or other building within the City of Crockett shall be $100.00. 
(Ord. No. O-03-14, § IV, 3-17-14) 
Secs. 5-502-5-525. - Reserved. 
Chapter 6 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Texas Disaster Act of 1975, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6889-7. 

Sec. 6-1. - Office of director of emergency management. 
    There exists the office of director of emergency management of the city which shall be held by the mayor in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 1, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-2. - Duties and responsibilities of director. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the emergency management director shall include the following: 
(1)  The direction and control of the actual disaster operations of the city emergency management organization as well as the training of emergency management personnel. 
(2)  The determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within the emergency management organization of the city. 
(3)  The maintenance of necessary liaisons with other municipal, county, district, state, regional, federal, or other emergency management organizations. 
(4)  The marshaling, after declaration of a disaster of all necessary personnel, equipment or supplies from any department of the city to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the city emergency management plan. 
(5)  The issuance of all necessary proclamations as to the existence of a disaster and the immediate operational effectiveness of the city emergency management plan. 
(6)  The issuance of reasonable rules, regulations or directives which are necessary for the protection of life and property in the city. The rules and regulations shall be filed in the office of the city secretary and shall receive widespread publicity unless publicity would be of aid and comfort to the enemy. 
(7)  The supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the state and of other local political subdivisions of the state, and the drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county in which the city is located and with other municipalities within the county, for the county-wide coordination of emergency management efforts. 
(8)  The supervision of, and final authorization for the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency management within the city. 
(9)  The authorizing of agreements, after approval by the city attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 4, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-3. - Appointment of coordinator. 
    An emergency management coordinator may be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the director of emergency management. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 1, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-4. - Conduct of comprehensive emergency management program. 
    The director of emergency management shall be responsible for conducting a program of comprehensive emergency management within the city and for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in section 6-2. The director may delegate authority for execution of these duties to the emergency management coordinator, but ultimate responsibility for such execution shall remain with the director. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 1, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-5. - General authority of director regarding hazard mitigation. 
    The powers and duties of the director of emergency management shall include the implementation of an on-going survey of actual or potential major hazards which threaten life and property within the city, and the implementation of an on-going program of identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures which would tend to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of hazards if a disaster did occur. As part of his responsibility in hazard mitigation, the director shall supervise the development of an emergency management plan for the city and shall recommend that plan for adoption by the city council along with any and all mutual aid plans and agreements which are deemed essential for the implementation of the emergency management plan. The powers of the director shall include the authority to declare a state of disaster, but such action may be subject to confirmation by the city council at its next meeting. The duties of the director shall also include the causing of a survey of the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies and services which could be used during a disaster as well as a continuing study of the need for amendments and improvements in the emergency management plan. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 2, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-6. - Formation of county-wide emergency management council. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized to join with the county judge and the mayors of the other cities in the county in the formation of an emergency management council for the county and shall have the authority to cooperate in the preparation of a joint emergency management plan and in the appointment of a joint emergency management coordinator, as well as all powers necessary to participate in a county-wide program of emergency management insofar as the program may affect the city. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 3, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-7. - City operational emergency management organization. 
(a)  The operational emergency management organization of the city shall consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated by the director in the emergency management plan, as well as all organized volunteer groups. 
(b)  The functions and duties of the operational emergency management organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the emergency management plan. The plan shall set forth the form of the organization, establish and designate divisions and functions, assign tasks, duties and powers, and designate officers and employees to carry out the provisions of this chapter. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the state division of emergency management and federal government. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 5, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-8. - Unauthorized use of sirens. 
    Any unauthorized person who shall operate a siren or other device so as to simulate a warning signal, or the termination of a warning, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this Code and shall be subject to the penalties prescribed by section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 6, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-9. - Emergency orders, rules, etc., to prevail over conflicting provisions. 
    At all times when the emergency orders, rules, and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be in effect, they shall supersede and override all existing provisions of this Code and other ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations which may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 7, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-10. - Conflict with provisions of state, federal, military rules, etc. 
    This chapter shall not be construed so as to conflict with any state or federal statute or with any military or naval order, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 8, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-11. - Nonliability of persons acting within scope of chapter provisions. 
(a)  This chapter is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety and neither the city, its agents and representatives or any other person who, in good faith, is carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with, any order, rule, or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons as the result of said activity. 
(b)  Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the city a license or otherwise permits the city to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack, together with his successors in interest, shall not be civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises under such license or other permission or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 9, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-12. - Use of public funds, binding city prohibited. 
    No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the city in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this chapter without prior approval by the city council, nor shall any person have any right to bind the city by contract, agreement or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 10, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-13. - Obstructing, hindering members of organization. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter, or to do any act forbidden by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 11, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-14. - Unlawful use of emblems, insignias, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wear, carry or display any emblem, insignia or any other means of identification as a member of the emergency management organization of the city, unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 11, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-15. - Oath. 
    Any person who is assigned a function or responsibility pursuant to this chapter shall solemnly swear or affirm to support and defend the Constitution of the United States, state laws and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-6E-82, § 12, 6-21-82) 
Sec. 6-16. - Hazard mitigation action plan. 
(a)  The City of Crockett has developed a hazard mitigation action plan to serve as a guiding document for local officials. 
(b)  The hazard mitigation action plan will be utilized by elected officials, city staff, and community members to ensure continuity of future mitigation programs and policies. 
(c)  The hazard mitigation action plan is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. No. O-09-04, 9-20-04; Ord. No. O-10-08, 10-6-08; Ord. No. O-11-09, 11-2-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09-04, adopted Sept. 20, 2004, did not expressly amend this Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as § 6-16 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Chapter 7 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Fire department, §§ 5.02, 7.01. 
Cross reference- Construction of buildings and structures within fire limits, § 5-20; electricity generally, § 5-116 et seq.; firearms, § 15-16 et seq. 
State Law reference- Fire prevention powers of city, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. arts. 1175(25), (34), 1011. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Arson reward. 
    The city hereby offers a reward of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the arrest and conviction of any person found guilty of committing the crime of arson within the city. This reward is a standing offer, and shall be paid out of the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3-23-64; Ord. No. O-10B-88, § 1, 10-17-88) 
Sec. 7-2. - Fireworks. 
(a)  Storage, sale, disposal, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to store, offer for sale, sell or otherwise dispose of or distribute, any fireworks or substances designed and intended for pyrotechnic displays, within the city limits. 
(b)  Discharge, use, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge, fire, or use fireworks or substances designed and intended for pyrotechnic display. Public display of fireworks by properly qualified individuals under the direct supervision of experts in handling of fireworks may be permitted. Such displays shall be of such a character and so located, discharged, and fired as, in the opinion of the city fire marshal or the chief of the fire department, shall not be hazardous to surrounding property or endanger any person. 
(c)  "Fireworks" defined. As used in this section, the term "fireworks" shall mean and include any firecrackers, cannon crackers, skyrockets, torpedoes, Roman candles, sparklers, squibs, fire balloons, star shells, gerbs, pistols, canes, cannons or other appliances, using blank cartridges or caps containing chlorate of potash mixture, or any other substance in whatever combination by any designated name intended for use in obtaining visible or audible pyrotechnic display and shall include all articles or substances within the commonly accepted meaning of fireworks, whether herein specifically designated and defined or not. 
(d)  Penalty for violation. If any person shall violate this section the violator will be prosecuted and charged a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. O-4-88, §§ 1-4, 4-4-88) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. O-4-88, adopted April 4, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-4 as § 7-2 was at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 7-3-7-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Application of fire prevention code to substandard buildings, § 5-426. 

Sec. 7-16. - Fire code adopted. 
    The International Fire Code, as now written and hereafter amended, is hereby adopted by the City of Crockett, Texas, and the provisions thereof are incorporated herein as fully as if set out at length herein. The provisions thereof shall be controlling within the city for all matters set forth therein. At least three (3) copies of the current version of the International Fire Code are now filed in the office of the city secretary, and as the International Fire Code is, from time to time, amended, at least three (3) copies of the International Fire Code and amendments shall be and remain filed in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 174-E, § 1, 6-17-74; Ord. No. O-8-91, § I, 8-19-91; Ord. No. O-5-97, § IX, 5-19-97; Ord. No. O-02-13, § I, 2-4-13) 
Sec. 7-17. - Term in code defined. 
    Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the fire prevention code adopted by this article, it shall be held to mean the city. 
Cross reference- Adoption of other technical codes: mechanical, § 5-1; building, § 5-16; housing, § 5-76; electrical, § 5-131; plumbing, § 5-271; gas, § 5-356. 
Sec. 7-18. - Enforcement of code. 
    The fire prevention code adopted by this article shall be enforced by the chief of the fire department and the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 174-E, § 2, 6-17-74) 
Secs. 7-19-7-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE MARSHAL 

Sec. 7-31. - Office created. 
    The office of fire marshal is hereby created. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-1) 
Sec. 7-32. - Independence of office. 
    The office of fire marshal shall be independent of other city departments, with the fire marshal reporting directly to the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-1) 
Sec. 7-33. - Appointment. 
    The office of fire marshal shall be filled by appointment pursuant to the provisions of section 7.01 of the Charter. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-1) 
Sec. 7-34. - Qualifications. 
    The fire marshal shall be properly qualified for the duties of his office in accordance with recognized standards. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-1) 
Sec. 7-35. - Removal. 
    The fire marshal shall be removed from office only for cause. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-1) 
Sec. 7-36. - Duty to investigate fires. 
    The fire marshal shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring within the city by which property has been destroyed or damaged, and shall especially make investigation as to whether the fire was the result of carelessness or design. The investigation shall be begun within twenty-four (24) hours, not including Sunday, of the occurrence of the fire. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-2) 
Sec. 7-37. - Taking of testimony generally. 
    The fire marshal, when in his opinion further investigation is necessary, shall take or cause to be taken the testimony, on oath, of all persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge in relation to the matter under investigation, and shall cause the same to be reduced to writing. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3) 
Sec. 7-38. - Summoning witnesses; obtaining evidence. 
    The fire marshal shall have the power to summon witnesses before him to testify in relation to any matter which is by the provisions of this article a subject of inquiry and investigation, and may require the production of any book, paper or document deemed pertinent thereto. The fire marshal is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and affirmations to any persons appearing as witnesses before him. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3) 
Sec. 7-39. - Privacy of investigations; separating witnesses. 
    All investigations held by or under the direction of the fire marshal may, in his discretion, be private, and persons other than those required to be present may be excluded from the place where such investigation is held, and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each other and not allowed to communicate with each other until they have been examined. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3) 
Sec. 7-40. - Duty when evidence indicates arson. 
    If the fire marshal shall be of the opinion that there is evidence sufficient to charge any person with the crime of arson, or with the attempt to commit the crime of arson, or of conspiracy to defraud, or criminal conduct in connection with a fire, he shall cause the person to be lawfully arrested and charged with such offense or either of them, and shall furnish to the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence, together with the names of witnesses and all of the information obtained by him, including a copy of all pertinent and material testimony taken in the case. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3) 
Sec. 7-41. - Misconduct of witnesses. 
    Any witness who refuses to be sworn, or who refuses to appear or testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the fire marshal, or who fails or refuses to produce any book, paper or document touching any matter under examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the proceedings of the fire marshal in the matter of said investigation or inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter under investigation as aforesaid, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor; and it shall be the duty of the fire marshal to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3) 
Sec. 7-42. - Right of entry. 
    The fire marshal shall have the authority at all times of day or night, when necessary, in the performance of the duties imposed upon him by the provisions of this article, to enter upon and examine any building or premises where any fire has occurred, and other buildings and premises adjoining or near the same, which authority shall be exercised only with reason and good discretion. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3) 
Sec. 7-43. - Inspection of premises. 
    The fire marshal, upon complaint of any person having an interest in any building or property adjacent and without any complaint, shall have a right at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of examination, to enter into and upon all buildings and premises within the city and to make a thorough examination thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3; Ord. No. O-8-91, § II, 8-19-91) 
Sec. 7-44. - Correction of dangerous conditions. 
    Whenever the fire marshal shall find any building or other structure which, for want of repair, or by reason of age or dilapidation condition, or for any cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger other buildings or property, or so occupied that fire would endanger persons or property therein, and whenever he shall find an improper or dangerous arrangement of stoves, ranges, furnaces or other heating appliances of any kind whatsoever, including chimneys, flues, and pipes with which the same may be connected, or a dangerous arrangement of lighting devices or systems, or a dangerous or unlawful storage of explosives, compounds, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, dangerous chemicals, vegetable products, ashes, or combustible, inflammable and refuse materials, or other conditions which may be dangerous in character or liable to cause or promote fire or create conditions dangerous to the firemen or occupants, he shall order the same to be removed or remedied, and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant of the building or premises; however, if the owner or occupant deems himself aggrieved by such order, he may, within five (5) days, appeal to the mayor, who shall investigate the cause of the complaint and unless by his authority the order is revoked, the order shall remain in force and be forthwith complied with by said owner or occupant. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3) 
Sec. 7-45. - Records. 
    The fire marshal shall keep in his office a record of all fires, together with all facts and the amount of the loss, which may be determined by the investigation required by this article. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-2) 
Sec. 7-46. - Monthly report. 
    At the end of each month the fire marshal shall report to the state fire marshal each fire in the city during the month. 
(Code 1960, § 1-13-3; Ord. No. O-8-91, § III, 8-19-91) 
Secs. 7-47-7-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONTROLLED FIRES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Burning of garbage prohibited, § 10-5. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-61. - Outdoor burning prohibited; exceptions. 
    No outdoor burning of trash, brush, grass, leaves, paper, trees, lumber or any other character of debris or material shall be permitted within the city, except as follows: 
(1)  Outdoor burning authorized by a written grant of authority from the Texas Air Control Board or its executive director, who before granting such authority, must determine that there is no practical alternative to outdoor burning and that the burning will not cause or contribute to a violation of any federal primary or secondary ambient air standard. 
(2)  Outdoor burning for the purpose of training fire fighting personnel when requested from and approved by the Texas Air Control Board pursuant to the regulations of the board. 
(3)  Outdoor burning of domestic waste and debris at and from a property designed for and used exclusively as a private residence, housing not more than three (3) families where collection of the waste or debris is not provided by the city. 
(4)  Outdoor burning consisting of fires used solely for ceremonial purposes. 
(5)  Outdoor burning of diseased animals when burning is the most effective means of controlling the spread of disease. 
(6)  Outdoor burning permitted pursuant to regulations now existing or hereafter adopted by the Texas Air Control board. 
(7)  Outdoor burning utilized for noncommercial preparation of food or for the purpose of supplying warmth during cold weather. 
(8)  Outdoor burning of vegetation in accordance with sections 7-91 through 7-95. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 1, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 7-62. - Incinerator burning. 
    Incinerator burning of waste and debris within the city shall comply with the then current requirements of the Texas Air Control Board. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 2, 10-15-79) 
Secs. 7-63-7-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TREES AND BRUSH[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Vegetation generally, § 20-1 et seq. 

Sec. 7-76. - When permitted. 
(a)  Outdoor burning of trees, brush, grass and other vegetable matter is permitted at the site of growth and only in accordance with the following: 
(1)  When no practical alternative to burning exists for right-of-way maintenance and land clearing operations. 
(2)  When it is necessary to eliminate a naturally occurring fire hazard. 
Sec. 7-77. - General requirements. 
    Outdoor burning pursuant to this division shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Burning shall be commenced only when the wind direction is such as to carry the smoke and other pollutants away from any city, residential, recreational, commercial or industrial area, or any navigable water, public road or landing strip which may be affected by the smoke. Burning shall not be conducted when a significant shift in wind direction is predicted which could produce adverse effects on persons, animals, or property during the burning period. If at any time the burning causes or may tend to cause smoke to blow onto or across a road or highway, it is the responsibility of the person initiating the burning to post flagmen on affected roads in accordance with the requirements of the state department of public safety. 
(2)  The burning must be at least three hundred (300) feet from any residential, recreational, commercial or industrial area except those located on the property where the burning is to take place, except when it is necessary to eliminate a naturally occurring fire hazard. 
(3)  Heavy oils, asphaltic materials, items containing natural or synthetic rubber or any materials other than dry plant growth which may produce unreasonable amounts of smoke must not be burned. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 1, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 7-78. - Hours of burning. 
    The hours for burning pursuant to this division shall comply with the following: 
(1)  The initiation of burning for land clearing and right-of-way maintenance purposes shall commence after 9:00 a.m. Material which will not be completely consumed before 5:00 p.m. shall not be added to the fire. 
(2)  The initiation of burning for crop and range management purposes shall commence after 9:00 a.m. The acreage to be burned should be adjusted to provide that the burning is completed by 5:00 p.m. on the same day or as soon as is reasonably practical. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 1, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 7-79. - Wind velocity. 
    Burning shall not be commenced when surface wind speed is predicted to be less than six (6) miles per hour or greater than twenty-three (23) miles per hour during the burn period. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 1, 10-15-79) 
Secs. 7-80-7-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 7-91. - Required. 
    No burning authorized by this article, except burning pursuant to section 7-61(7), shall commence prior to the issuance of a permit by the fire marshal and the fire chief after a finding that no practical alternative exists to the burning and that the danger to adjoining property is minimal or can be controlled. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 3, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 7-92. - Contents of permit. 
    A permit issued pursuant to this division shall state the following: 
(1)  The name of the permittee. 
(2)  The type of material to be burned. 
(3)  The location of the burning. 
(4)  The date and time of the burning. 
(5)  A statement that the permittee is to assume all liability and responsibility for the fire and damage or destruction occurring therefrom. 
(6)  A statement that the fire must be supervised and guarded at any time while it is burning and that a water supply and hose will be available to control the fire at all times. 
(7)  Any special requirements which in the opinion of the fire marshal are required to conduct a safe burning. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 3, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 7-93. - Fees and costs. 
    No fee shall be charged for the issuance of a permit required by this division; however, in the event special requirements of the fire chief or fire marshal will result in additional costs to the city, said costs shall be paid by the permittee upon the issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 5, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 7-94. - Appeal from denial of permit. 
    In the event that the fire marshal and fire chief shall refuse to issue a burning permit, the applicant may appeal to the city council within ten (10) days of the refusal by giving written notice of appeal to the city administrator. The council shall consider the application for a permit de novo. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 4, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 7-95. - Permittee liable for damages; compliance with other regulations. 
    The authority to conduct outdoor burning under this article does not exempt or excuse the permittee from the consequences, damages, or injuries resulting from the burning and does not exempt or excuse any person from complying with all other applicable laws or ordinances, regulations and orders of governmental entities having jurisdiction, even though the burning is otherwise conducted in compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. O-10C-79, § 3, 10-15-79) 
Secs. 7-96-7-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FIRE LANES 

Sec. 7-100. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings set out in this section.
