Sec. 10-31. - Rates outside city. 
    The rates to be charged for the collection of garbage outside the city limits shall be two hundred (200) percent of the rates charged to customers within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. O-8-84, § 4, 8-23-84) 
Sec. 10-32. - Private collecting prohibited. 
    The collection of garbage, trash, rubbish or junk within the city is prohibited except as otherwise provided for in this chapter. Garbage and refuse collection by private commercial companies within the city limits is prohibited unless approved by the city council. 
(Code 1960, § 11-3-13; Ord. No. O-09F-05, § V, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 10-33. - Waste motor oil. 
    Residents may drop off waste motor oil originating in the city at the city waste drop-off site. Residents must show a copy of a current water bill in the resident's name to gain entrance to the city waste drop-off site. Residents will not be charged to use the city waste drop-off site for drop off of waste motor oil originating in the city. Businesses may not drop off waste motor oil at the city waste drop-off site. 
(Ord. No. O-09D-15, § VI, 9-21-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09D-15, § VI, adopted Sept. 21, 2015, amended § 10-33 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 10-33 was entitled "Rates for open top roll-off container rental", and derived from: Ord. No. O-01-07, § I, adopted Jan. 16, 2007; and Ord. No. O-10-10, § III, adopted Oct. 4, 2010. 
Sec. 10-34. - Collection of recyclables. 
    The private contractor collecting trash and garbage for the city shall accept from city residents all recyclables, except glass, which were accepted by the city prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section. The private contractor will provide within the city limits a collection point for recyclable material. The collection point shall be open from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. one (1) day each month. The date shall be designated by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. O-09D-15, § VII, 9-21-15; Ord. No. O-12C-15 , § II, 12-7-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09D-15, § VII, adopted Sept. 21, 2015, amended § 10-34 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 10-34 was entitled "Rates for disposal of residential construction and demolition material delivered by residential customers", and derived from Ord. No. O-01-07, § II, adopted Jan. 16, 2007. 
Sec. 10-35. - Disposal of used vehicle tires. 
(a)  Residents may deliver used vehicle tires to the city waste drop-off site for a charge of five dollars ($5.00) per tire for car or truck tires twenty-two (22) inches in diameter and below, and a charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per tire for tires greater than twenty-two (22) inches in diameter. Residents must show a copy of a current water bill in the resident's name to gain entrance to the city waste drop-off site. 
(b)  No commercial or heavy equipment tires will be accepted at the city waste drop-off site. 
(c)  Residents may not deliver more than one (1) set of four (4) vehicle tires per calendar year to the city waste drop-off site. 
(Ord. No. O-01-07, § III, 1-16-07; Ord. No. O-09D-15, § VIII, 9-21-15; Ord. No. O-12C-15 , § III, 12-7-15) 
Secs. 10-36-10-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY SOLID WASTE TRANSFER POINT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09E-10, § I, adopted Sept. 7, 2010, renamed art. III, which was entitled "City Landfill" as set out herein. 

Sec. 10-46. - Use required. 
    Garbage, refuse, trash, rubbish and any other material regulated by this article shall not be disposed of in any manner other than through the City of Crockett Solid Waste Department. 
(Code 1960, § 11-3-9; Ord. No. O-09F-05, § VI, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 10-47. - Separating and collecting items prohibited. 
    All junk and other material located at the city transfer point is the property of the city, and no person is allowed to separate and collect, carry off or dispose of the same, except under the direction of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 11-3-12; Ord. No. O-09F-05, § VII, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 10-48. - Persons and property authorized to enter the city waste drop-off site. 
    Officers and agents of the private contractor collecting trash and garbage for the City of Crockett, officers of the city, employees of the city employed at the city waste drop-off site and those persons delivering yard debris, waste, motor oil and tires are allowed upon the grounds of the city solid waste transfer site, and all other persons are prohibited therefrom. No one may transport household garbage or refuse into the city waste drop-off site under any circumstances. Nonresidents may not deliver material to the city waste drop-off site, nor shall materials originating outside the city be delivered to the city waste drop-off site. Heavy accumulations such as brick, broken concrete, lumber, ashes, cinders, dirt, plaster, sand, gravel, appliances, automobile frames, dead trees, other bulky or heavy material, pieces of wood, barrels, crates, scraps of iron, wire or any other metals shall not be delivered to the city waste drop-off site. 
(Ord. of 7-10-72, § 2; Ord. No. O-09F-05, § VIII, 9-6-05; Ord. No. O-09D-15, § IX, 9-21-15) 
Sec. 10-49. - Franchise fees. 
(a)  The private contractor collecting solid waste for the city shall pay the city a franchise fee equal to twelve (12) percent of the gross collections for residential collection. 
(b)  The private contractor collecting solid waste for the city shall pay the city a franchise fee equal to ten (10) percent of the gross collections for commercial collection. 
(c)  The private contractor collecting solid waste for the city shall pay the city a franchise fee equal to ten (10) percent of the gross collections for roll-off fees. 
(Ord. No. O-09D-15, § X, 9-21-15) 
Secs. 10-50-10-65. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 10-100. - Violation of chapter. 
(a)  Violation of any duty imposed by this chapter, the commission of any act prohibited by this chapter, the failure to perform any act required thereunder, or the commission of any act defined to be unlawful or an offense thereunder, shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any person who by act of either omission or commission commits such misdemeanor or causes same to be committed shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day of violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing subsection (a) the violation of section 10-1, Prohibited Dumping, of the Crockett Code shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00). 
(c)  Notwithstanding the foregoing subsections (a) and (b), the penalties of this section shall not apply to violations of section 10-200. 
(Ord. No. O-2-93, § VII, 2-1-93; Ord. No. O-04-07, § 1, 4-16-07; Ord. No. O-12D-15 ) 
Secs. 10-101-10-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SCRAP TIRES 

Sec. 10-200. - Marking scrap tires by tire dealers. 
(a)  The term "scrap tire" means a tire that can no longer be used for its original intended purpose. 
(b)  No person, firm or organization engaged in the business of selling tires shall possess a scrap tire which is not marked in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(c)  Each tire dealer shall mark scrap tires in accordance with this section in a color assigned to the dealer by the code enforcement officer. No two (2) dealers shall be assigned the same color by the code enforcement officer. 
(d)  Scrap tires shall be marked across the sidewall from the center to the outer edge with a single painted stripe, which must be at least one (1) inch in width and in the dealer's assigned color. In the event the tire has no sidewall, it shall be marked completely across the tread with a single painted stripe, which must be at least one (1) inch in width and in the dealer's assigned color. 
(Ord. No. O-04-07, § 2, 4-16-07) 
Sec. 10-201. - Penalty. 
    An offense under section 10-200 is punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. 
(Ord. No. O-04-07, § 3, 4-16-07)

ARTICLE II. - HEALTH NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Rabies control, § 4-36 et seq.; duty of property owners to trim trees and hedges, § 20-1. 

Sec. 11-16. - Stagnant water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or occupy any lot in the city to permit or allow holes or places on said lot where water may accumulate and become stagnant, or to permit same to remain. It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or occupy any lot in the city to permit or allow the accumulation of stagnant water thereon, or to permit same to remain. 
State Law reference- Power of city to so provide, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4436. 
Sec. 11-17. - Accumulations of carrion, filth etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or occupy any house, buildings, establishment, lot or yard in the city to permit or allow any carrion, filth or other impure or unwholesome matter to accumulate or remain thereon. 
State Law reference- Power of city to so provide, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4436. 
Sec. 11-18. - Growth or accumulation of weeds, grass or plants; duty to cut, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner of real property to: 
(1)  Permit weeds, grass, brush or plants that are not cultivated to grow upon said premises to a greater height than twelve (12) inches on average or to grow in rank profusion thereon; 
(2)  Keep, store or accumulate refuse, unless the refuse is entirely contained in a closed receptacle; 
(3)  Keep, store or accumulate rubbish, including newspapers, abandoned vehicles, refrigerators, stoves, furniture, tires, and cans, unless the rubbish is completely enclosed in a building and is not visible from a public street; or 
(4)  Maintain the premises in a manner that creates an unsanitary condition likely to attract or harbor mosquitos, rodents, vermin or disease-carrying pests. 
Any such premises shall be deemed a public nuisance. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any owner of any premises to remove or cause to be removed or cut all weeds, grass, brush or plants that are not cultivated as often as may be necessary to comply with subsection (a) of this section and to remove any other matter prohibited by this section; provided, however, that the removal and cutting of said weeds, grass, brush or plants that are not cultivated at least once every three (3) weeks during the period between June 1 and October 1 shall be deemed to be in compliance with subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. O-12B-13, § I, 12-9-13) 
State Law reference- Power of city to so provide, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4436. 
Sec. 11-19. - Notice to correct or remove condition. 
    In the event that any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property permits any condition to exist thereon in violation of this article, the city shall notify such person of his failure to comply and direct him to correct, remedy, or remove such condition within ten (10) days after such notice. Such notice shall be sent to the person by certified or registered mail with a five-day return requested. The property owner or agent's name and address will be taken from the city tax rolls as obtained from the Houston County Central Appraisal District. If the person's correct address cannot be obtained and notification cannot be made by letter, notice shall be given by publication in two (2) consecutive issues of the Houston County Courier, Crockett, Texas. 
(Ord. No. O-7C-85, § 2, 7-15-85) 
State Law reference- Required notice, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4436. 
Sec. 11-20. - Correction or removal of condition by city. 
(a)  If the owner of real property permits any condition to exist thereon in violation of this article, the city may give notice of the violation in the following manner: 
(1)  Personally to the owner in writing; 
(2)  By letter addressed to the owner at the owner's address as recorded in the appraisal district records of the appraisal district in which the property is located; or 
(3)  If personal service cannot be obtained: 
a.  By publication one (1) time in the Houston County Courier, Crockett, Texas; 
b.  By posting the notice on or near the front door of each building on the property to which the violation relates; or 
c.  By posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the property to which the violation relates. 
(b)  If the city mails a notice to a property owner in accordance with this section and the United States Postal Service returns the notice as "Refused" or "Unclaimed," the validity of the notice is not affected, and the notice is considered as delivered. 
(c)  If the owner of the property fails or refuses to correct, remedy or remove the condition specified in the notice within seven (7) days after notice of the violation, the city may: 
(1)  Do the work or make the improvements required; or 
(2)  Pay for the work done or improvements made and charge the expenses to the owner of the property. 
(d)  In a notice provided under this section, the city may inform the owner by regular mail and a posting on the property, or by personally delivering the notice, that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary of the date of the notice, the city without further notice may correct the violation at the owner's expense and assess the expense against the property. If a violation covered by a notice under this subsection occurs within a one-year period, and the city has not been informed in writing by the owner of an ownership change, then the city without notice may take the action permitted by subsections (c)(1) and (2) and assess its expenses as provided by section 11-20.1. 
(Ord. No. O-7C-85, § 3, 7-15-85; Ord. No. O-09B-02, § I, 9-16-02) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4436. 
Sec. 11-20.1. - Assessment of expenses; lien. 
(a)  The city may assess expenses incurred under section 11-20 against the real estate on which the work is done or improvements made. 
(b)  To obtain a lien against the property, the mayor, municipal health officer or municipal official designated by the mayor must file a statement of expenses with the County Clerk of Houston County, Texas. The lien statement must state the name of the owner, if known, and the legal description of the property. The lien attaches upon the filing of the lien statement with the county clerk. 
(c)  The lien is security for the expenditures made and interest accruing at the rate of ten (10) percent on the amount due from the date of payment by the city. 
(d)  The lien is inferior only to: 
(1)  Tax liens; and 
(2)  Liens for street improvements. 
(e)  The city may bring a suit for foreclosure in the name of the city to recover the expenditures and interest due. 
(f)  The statement of expenses or a certified copy of the statement is prima facie proof of the expenses incurred by the city in doing the work or making the improvements. 
(Ord. No. O-09B-02, § II, 9-16-02) 
Sec. 11-20.2. - Additional authority to abate dangerous weeds. 
(a)  The city may abate, without notice, weeds that: 
(1)  Have grown higher than forty-eight (48) inches; and 
(2)  Are an immediate danger to the health, life or safety of any person. 
(b)  Not later than the tenth day after the date the city abates weeds under this section, the city shall give notice to the property owner in the manner required by section 11-20. 
(c)  The notice shall contain: 
(1)  An identification, which is not required to be a legal description, of the property; 
(2)  A description of the violations of the ordinance that occurred on the property; 
(3)  A statement that the municipality abated the weeds; and 
(4)  An explanation of the property owner's right to request an administrative hearing about the municipality's abatement of the weeds. 
(d)  The code enforcement officer shall conduct an administrative hearing on the abatement of weeds under this section if, not later than the thirtieth day after the date of the abatement of the weeds, the property owner files with the city a written request for a hearing. 
(e)  An administrative hearing conducted under this section shall be conducted not later than the twentieth day after the date a request for hearing is filed. The owner may testify or present any witnesses or written information relating to the city's abatement of the weeds. 
(f)  The city may assess expenses and create liens under this section as it assesses expenses and creates liens under section 11-20.1. A lien created under this section is subject to the same conditions as a lien created under section 11-20.1. 
(g)  The authority granted by this section is in addition to the authority granted by section 11-20. 
(Ord. No. O-09B-02, § III, 9-16-02) 
Sec. 11-21. - Violations. 
    Any person notified as provided in section 11-19 who fails or refuses to correct or remove the condition specified in such notice within ten (10) days after the date of notification by letter or within ten (10) days after the date of second publication of the notice in the newspaper, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and issued a warrant to appear in municipal court. Each and every day that the violation remains uncorrected shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. In case the owner or occupant of any lot or premises under the provisions of this article shall be a corporation, and shall violate any provision of this article, the president, vice president, secretary, treasurer of such corporation or any manager, agent or employee of such corporation shall be also severally liable for the penalties herein provided. 
State Law reference- Power of city to so provide, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4436; responsibility of corporations for violations, V.T.C.A. Penal Code, § 7-21 et seq. 
Sec. 11-22. - Appeal to district court. 
    Any interested person may appeal a determination by the city under sections 11-20, 11-20.1 or 11-20.2 within thirty (30) days after a copy of the determination of the city is delivered, mailed, published or posted, by filing a verified petition with the District Court of Houston County, Texas stating that the decision is illegal in whole or in part. Review by the district court shall be de novo, and the district court may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-09D-12, § I, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 11-23. - Disposal of grass clippings, leaves and tree limbs. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each owner, occupant and person in charge of premises and each person performing labor on-premises to insure that all grass clippings, leaves and tree limbs are properly disposed of without creating a health or safety hazard. No one shall blow, rake or sweep or otherwise place grass clippings, tree limbs or leaves on any city street within the City of Crockett. No person shall cause grass clippings, tree limbs or leaves to be dumped, raked or otherwise placed into ditches, creeks or streams within the City of Crockett. 
(b)  The refuse control officer may issue a citation to appear in municipal court to any person he believes has violated the provisions of this section. Any violation of the provisions of this section is punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. 
(Ord. No. O-04-B-10, § 1, 4-5-10; Ord. No. O-09D-12, § I, 9-4-12) 
Editor's note- Formerly codified as § 11-22, which was renumbered as set out herein, due to the inclusion of a new § 11-22 added by Ord. No. O-09D-12. 
Secs. 11-24-11-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMBULANCES; EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-12-05, §§ 1, 2, adopted Dec. 5, 2005, repealed the former art. III., §§ 11-36-11-58, and enacted a new art. III as set out herein. The former art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-5-83, §§ 1, 2, adopted Mar. 16, 1983; Ord. No. O-10A-83, adopted Oct. 3, 1983; Ord. No. O-2A-84, adopted Feb. 20, 1984; Ord. No. O-10B-84, § I, adopted Oct. 1, 1984; Ord. No. O-8A-85, §§ 1, 2, adopted Aug. 19, 1985; Ord. No. O-4A-86, § 1, adopted Apr. 21, 1986 and Ord. No. O-9-86, § 1, adopted Sept. 15, 1986. 
State Law reference- Ambulances, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4590b. 

Sec. 11-36. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the intent of this section to: 
(1)  Establish a regulated ambulance service system, which can provide clinical quality of care, with reasonable, reliable response time standards, and with the goal of furnishing the best possible chance of survival, without disability or preventable complication, to each ambulance patient. 
(2)  Establish a sole-provider ambulance system, because it is unreasonable to have unnecessarily high rates and/or public subsidy to make needed improvements to ambulance service in the service area, when a more efficiently designed system can achieve the same results at a lower cost. The most efficient design to achieve the goals of high-quality service, at the lowest cost, consistent with the quality of care required, is the implementation of the system described herein. 
(3)  Provide a method to develop specific performance standards, adequate review, and either a continuation of service or an appropriate procedure to obtain alternate proposals from other providers. 
(4)  Provide more effective medical oversight by recognizing a medical director who is a licensed physician expert in emergency medicine and related specialties as the individual empowered to oversee all clinical aspects of the emergency medical system that affect patient care within this jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. O-12-05, § 2, 12-5-05) 
Sec. 11-37. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases as used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
    Ambulance: Any privately or publicly owned motor vehicle that is specially designed or constructed and equipped and is intended to be used for and is maintained or operated for the transportation of patients. 
    Ambulance patient or patient: Any person being transported in a reclining position, whose transport originates within the city limits, to or from a health care facility. 
    Ambulance service contractor: That entity which is then currently under contract to provide all ambulance and ambulance patient services within the city limits, except those services specifically exempted by section 11-38 of this article. 
    Contract/regulated service area: The geographic area encompassing the city and other such areas where the city may be responsible for the provision of public safety service, including ambulance service. This includes and is defined as the geographical area within the city and the surrounding areas served by the city water system. 
    EMS system: That network of individuals, organizations, facilities and equipment whose participation is required to generate a clinically-appropriate, pre-planned, system-wide response for pre-hospital care and transport or interfacility transport, so as to provide each patent the best possible chance of survival without disability, given available financial resources and EMS technology. 
    Person: Any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, governmental agency, or other group or combination acting as a unit. 
    Special event: Any public event located within the regulated service area, for which standby ambulance service is arranged in advance, and for which an ambulance (or ambulances) are hired by the sponsor of the event or other interested party. 
(Ord. No. O-12-05, § 2, 12-5-05) 
Sec. 11-38. - Authority to operate-Exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall operate or cause to be operated an ambulance, nor furnish, conduct, maintain, advertise or otherwise be engaged in the business or service of the transportation of ambulance patients within the regulated service area, or provide special event standby coverage, unless such person is the ambulance service contractor. No person shall knowingly solicit ambulance services regulated herein except the ambulance service contractor. 
(b)  However, the prohibitions set forth in subsection (a), immediately above, shall not be applicable to an ambulance service provider: 
(1)  Which is rendering assistance to patients in the case of a major catastrophe or emergency with which the contractor's ambulances are insufficient or unable to cope; or is 
(2)  Transporting a patient who is picked up from a location beyond the regulated service area and transported to a location within the regulated service area; or is 
(3)  Transporting a patient who is picked up from a location beyond the regulated service area and transported to a location beyond the limits of the regulated service area and only incidentally passing through the regulated service area; or is 
(4)  Transporting a patient who is picked up from a location within the regulated service area and transported to a location outside the regulated service area. 
(Ord. No. O-12-05, § 2, 12-5-05) 
Sec. 11-39. - Compliance with law. 
    All persons and entities regulated under this section shall comply with the laws of the state and reference to permits, licenses, minimum equipment and minimum qualifications of operators and attendants and all state and federal laws and regulations applicable to its ambulance operation. 
(Ord. No. O-12-05, § 2, 12-5-05) 
Secs. 11-40-11-65. - Reserved. 
Chapter 12 - LIBRARY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Establishment and maintenance of free public library, § 3.11(p). 

Sec. 12-1. - Overdue materials; charges. 
(a)  Any material borrowed from the city library shall be deemed delinquent if it is not returned within twenty-one (21) days from the day it is borrowed. 
(b)  Overdue charges shall be twenty-five cents ($0.25) per day, not to exceed a total charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per item. 
(Ord. No. O-9-81, § 1, 9-8-81; Ord. No. O-10C-02, § I, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 12-2. - Lost books. 
    If a book or periodical is lost and cannot be returned, the patron shall pay the city public library the cost of the item as listed in the most current issue of Books in Print in effect on the date of the loss. 
(Ord. No. O-9-81, § 1, 9-8-81) 
Sec. 12-3. - Failure to return library materials. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he or she intentionally or knowingly fails to return library materials to the city public library which were loaned to such person or borrowed in such person's name with his consent. 
(b)  Intent or knowledge as used in subsection (a) shall be presumed if: 
(1)  Pursuant to the agreement, the library materials were to be returned to the library on a date specified. 
(2)  Actual notice is given or notice in writing is sent by depositing in the United States mail a notice addressed to the patron at his address as shown on the records of the library stating that the library materials were not returned on the date specified. 
(3)  The library material is not returned to the library within twenty (20) days of receipt of the notice. 
(c)  When the notice required by subsection (b)(2) has been sent and the library materials have not been returned within twenty (20) days of the receipt of the notice, the library shall send a second notice to the patron and if the patron shall neglect to return the library materials within ten (10) days of the mailing of the second notice, the patron shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(d)  If a notice is given in accordance with subsections (b) or (c), it shall be presumed that the notice was received no later than five (5) days after it was sent. 
(Ord. No. O-9-81, § 1, 9-8-81) 
Sec. 12-4. - Action in municipal court. 
(a)  Charges may be filed in the municipal court for violation of this chapter, upon proper complaint. 
(b)  In prosecutions brought under this chapter, it is no defense that the patron, though the actual borrower, no longer possesses the library materials. The patron is responsible for the library materials when they are checked out. 
(c)  In a prosecution under this chapter, it is an affirmative defense that another borrowed the library material in the name of the patron without his effective consent. 
(d)  Upon conviction of an offense under this chapter, the patron shall be fined an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each item. 
(Ord. No. O-9-81, § 1, 9-8-81; Ord. No. O-10C-02, § II, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 12-5. - Responsibility of parents for acts of minors. 
    A parent or legal guardian of a child under the age of eighteen (18) years at the time library material is borrowed from the city public library shall be responsible for violation of this chapter by their child. 
(Ord. No. O-9-81, § 1, 9-8-81) 
Chapter 13 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Certification of food handlers, § 9-16 et seq.; hotel occupancy tax, § 18-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. arts. 1015, 1175(34). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Establishments in which alcoholic beverages are consumed. 
(a)  In this section "establishment" means any privately owned place of business operating for profit to which the public is invited and in which alcoholic beverages are consumed or have been consumed within the past twenty-four (24) hours, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment, including dance halls and music venues. 
(b)  No establishment may remain open or have any customers on the premises between the hours of 12:15 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Monday through Saturday and between the hours of 1:15 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday. 
(c)  No establishment may hold any private party on the premises, between the hours of 12:15 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Monday through Saturday and between the hours of 1:15 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday. 
(d)  This section does not apply to any establishment permitted by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission to remain open after those hours. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent or person in charge of an establishment to allow any customer or other person not an employee of the establishment to remain on the premises or to hold any private party on the premises between the hours of 12:15 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Monday through Saturday and between the hours of 1:15 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday, and such activity is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and a violation of this section. 
(f)  Any person violating the provisions of this section is guilty of a class C misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not more than allowed by law. 
(g)  In addition, or as an alternative thereto, the city may, in the event of such violation, obtain injunctive relief in an appropriate court with jurisdiction in Houston County, Texas. 
(Ord. No. O-08B-10, § 1, 8-16-10; Ord. No. O-03-13, § 1, 3-4-13) 
Secs. 13-2-13-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-12-04, § 1, adopted Dec. 6, 2004, repealed provisions formerly set out as art. II, §§ 13-16-13-20, 13-26-13-49, of this chapter, which pertained to peddlers, itinerant vendors, and commercial amusement operators and derived from Ord. No. O-11-83, §§ 1, 3-10, 12-16, adopted Nov. 7, 1983; and Ord. No. O-10A-86, §§ 2-9, adopted Oct. 20, 1986. Section 2 of Ord. No. O-12-04 added new provisions to this chapter which have been included herein as arts. II-IV at the editor's discretion. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion of the provisions of Ord. No. O-12-04. 

Sec. 13-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler means any person who engages in a temporary business within the city limits and who sells or offers for sale for immediate delivery such goods or merchandise from house-to-house, business-to-business or upon public property. 
    Solicitor means any person who engages in a temporary business within the city limits and who solicits or attempts to solicit, from house-to-house, business-to-business or upon public property, goods, wares, merchandise, subscriptions, or publications to be delivered at a future date or time or orders for services to be performed at any time. The term "canvasser" is included under this definition of "solicitor". 
    A merchant shall be considered temporarily in business unless it is the intention of such merchant to remain continuously in business at each location where the merchant is engaged in business in the city as a merchant for a period of sixty (60) days or more and unless the merchant does in fact so remain continuously in business for sixty (60) days or more. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.010), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-17. - Permit-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any peddler or solicitor to engage in business within the city without first obtaining a permit from the code enforcement officer as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.020), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-18. - Permit-Exemptions. 
    The following are excluded from permitting provisions: 
(1)  Newspaper carriers; 
(2)  Farmers who sell agricultural products that were raised or grown by them; 
(3)  Locally-based nonprofit organizations; however, they are required to notify the code enforcement officer, at least three (3) business days in advance of any campaign, as to the approximate dates of the campaign, the areas in which they will be selling, and a description of items and services to be sold. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.030), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-19. - Permit-Written application required. 
    Any peddler or solicitor desiring to engage in business within the city must file a written application for a permit with the code enforcement officer, which application shall give the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's name, telephone number, address, birthdate, physical description and either: 
a.  Driver's license number and state; or 
b.  Social Security number and an official, government-issued picture identification card; 
(2)  If the applicant is peddling or making solicitations for any commercial, charitable or political organization, the name, telephone number and address of such organization; 
(3)  A full and complete list of goods to be sold and/or services to be performed; 
(4)  For each individual involved in the peddling or solicitation campaign: Name, telephone number, address, birthdate, physical description and either: 
a.  Driver's license number and state; or 
b.  Social Security number and an official, government-issued picture identification card; 
(5)  Description (year, make, type) and license plate number and state of all vehicles to be used in soliciting and peddling; 
(6)  A surety bond approved by the code enforcement officer or a cash bond, in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned that the applicant comply with all provisions of the Crockett Code and all other applicable state and federal laws and regulations. 
(7)  Satisfactory proof that the applicant possesses a valid Texas sales tax permit. 
    The applicant must provide original identifying documents to the code enforcement officer upon request. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.040), 12-6-04; Ord. No. O-08-12, § 1, 8-6-12) 
Sec. 13-20. - Permit-Fees. 
(a)  All peddlers and solicitors not exempted by section 13-21 shall pay a permit fee to the city secretary of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for one (1) individual and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional person. 
(b)  All peddlers and solicitors not exempted by section 13-21 shall pay to the City of Crockett the cost incurred by the city in conducting a background check with the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.050), 12-6-04; Ord. No. O-08-12, § 2, 8-6-12) 
Sec. 13-21. - Permit-Fees-Exemptions. 
    The following are exempt from the permit fee: 
(a)  Any individual soliciting or peddling for a philanthropic, charitable, political or religious organization; 
(b)  Any individual engaged in interstate commerce. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.060), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-22. - Permit-Denial. 
(a)  A copy of the application for permit will be referred to the chief of police, who will undertake an investigation of the applicant's record and background, such as shall be reasonably necessary to protect the public. An application for permit under this article may be denied where: 
(1)  Required application information is incomplete or incorrect; 
(2)  Applicant is currently wanted on a warrant for arrest; 
(3)  Applicant has been finally convicted of an offense under Chapter 21, 22, 29, 30, 31 or 32 of the Penal Code of the State of Texas or of a crime committed in another jurisdiction which, if it had been committed in the State of Texas, would be classified under one (1) or more of said chapters. 
(b)  If the code enforcement officer denies a permit, the applicant may appeal this decision in writing to the planning and zoning commission. A subcommittee of the planning and zoning commission, composed of the chairman of the commission and two (2) members of the commission appointed by the chairman, shall decide whether to affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the code enforcement officer by majority vote. If the subcommittee denies a permit, the applicant may appeal this decision in writing to the city council, which may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the subcommittee. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.070), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-23. - Permit-Issuance, duration. 
(a)  If the code enforcement officer or appellate authority finds that the application is completed in conformance with sections 13-19 through 13-22, a permit shall be issued within one (1) working day. The permit shall be the original application under section 13-19, with an official stamp indicating approval by the code enforcement officer. Each permit will be valid for one (1) month from date of issue; 
(b)  The code enforcement officer will retain one (1) copy of the approved permit for official records. The permit may not be represented as an endorsement or approval by the City of Crockett of the purposes of a solicitation or a product offered by the permittee; 
(c)  One (1) copy of the approved permit will be sent to the chief of police; 
(d)  Only those peddlers or solicitors whose names are listed on the approved application may conduct business under the issued permit. If any new peddlers or solicitors join the campaign after the original permit is issued, they must supply the code enforcement officer with the information required in section 13-19. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.080), 12-6-04; Ord. No. O-08-12, § 3, 8-6-12) 
Sec. 13-24. - Permit-Display. 
    Each peddler or solicitor will carry his or her permit at all times while engaging in business in the city. Upon request or demand of a peace officer, the peddler or solicitor will exhibit the permit to indicate compliance with all of the relevant requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.090), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-25. - Permit-Non-transferability. 
    Permits issued under the provisions of this article are not transferable in any situation and will be clearly marked "Not Transferable." 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.100), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-26. - Permit-Suspension. 
(a)  The chief of police or the chief's designee may, upon documented violation of law or endangerment of public welfare, health or safety by a peddler or solicitor, suspend and confiscate a permit issued under this article. 
(b)  Peddlers and solicitors whose licenses are suspended have three (3) business days during which to request an administrative review by the code enforcement officer of the suspension. If request for administrative review is not made within three (3) working days, the permit is revoked. If the code enforcement officer decides to suspend or revoke the permit, the permit holder may appeal this decision in writing to the planning and zoning commission. A subcommittee of the planning and zoning commission, composed of the chairman of the commission and two (2) members of the commission appointed by the chairman shall decide whether to affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the code enforcement officer by majority vote. If the subcommittee suspends or revokes a permit, the permit holder may appeal this decision in writing to the city council, which may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the subcommittee. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.110), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-27. - Permit-Revocation. 
(a)  Upon a permittee's request, the code enforcement officer shall provide the permittee with written notice containing the particulars of any and all complaints against the permittee and the time, date and place for an administrative review of the suspension. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer will conduct an administrative review to determine whether the permit shall be restored or revoked. 
(c)  After notice and review, the code enforcement officer may revoke any permit issued under this article for the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraudulent statements or omissions on a permit application or in conduct of permitted business; 
(2)  Violation of law; 
(3)  Endangerment of public welfare, health or safety. 
(d)  If the code enforcement officer revokes a permit, the permittee may appeal the decision in writing to the planning and zoning commission. A subcommittee of the planning and zoning commission, composed of the chairman of the commission and two (2) members of the commission appointed by the chairman, shall decide whether to affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the code enforcement officer, by majority vote. If the subcommittee revokes a permit, the permit holder may appeal this decision in writing to the city council. The city council may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the code enforcement officer. 
(e)  Revocation of any permit shall bar the permittee from eligibility for any permit under this article for a period of one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.120), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-28. - Hours of operation. 
    No peddler or solicitor may conduct activities defined in section 13-16 except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and sunset. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.130), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-29. - No solicitor signs. 
    Any peddler or solicitor who conducts or attempts to conduct business at a place where a sign clearly indicates that solicitors or peddlers are unwelcome is in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.140), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-30. - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article is guilty of a class C misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not more than allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.150), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-31. - Peddlers and solicitors prohibited in downtown area. 
    No peddler or solicitor shall engage in business in the downtown area. The downtown area is the area highlighted in yellow on the attached map (map of file with the city). 
(Ord. No. O-08-12, § 4, 8-6-12) 
Secs. 13-32-13-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CARNIVALS AND CIRCUSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Note- See the editor's note to art. II of this chapter. 

Sec. 13-36. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to show or conduct any carnival or circus within the city limits without first obtaining a license to do so from the city council. Any person showing or exhibiting, or in any manner connected with or taking part in the showing or exhibiting of, a carnival or circus within the city limits without first applying for and obtaining such a license shall be deemed guilty of a class C misdemeanor and fined not more than allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.210), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-37. - Application for license. 
(a)  Filing of application. Any person desiring to conduct or show a carnival or circus within the city limits shall make application for a license to the city council and file the same with the code enforcement officer not less than two (2) weeks prior to the time when it is desired to show or conduct such carnival or circus. Such application shall give the name and permanent address of the owner of the carnival or circus, and, if the carnival or circus is owned by a company or corporation, the application shall show such fact and shall show the name and address of the manager or other officer in charge of the carnival or circus. In any event, the application shall identify the person in active charge and control of showing and conducting the carnival or circus. The application shall further list all shows, rides, booths, and other businesses and attractions operated in connection with the carnival or circus and the location within the city where such carnival or circus is to be held. Such applicant shall also submit with the application, in the form of affidavits and financial statements, evidence as to the solvency and responsibility of the owner of the carnival or circus. In making such application, the person making same shall also pledge to conduct the carnival or circus and each and all of the shows, attractions, rides, booths, businesses and exhibits therein in an orderly and law-abiding manner. 
(b)  Approval of application. After an application is filed under this section, the code enforcement officer shall refer the same to the city council for action, and if the city council is convinced from the evidence submitted that the owner of the carnival or circus is solvent and that he has in the past conducted and proposes to conduct, while showing in the city, the carnival or circus in a decent, orderly, and law-abiding manner, the city council shall approve the application. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.220), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-38. - Fee for license. 
    As a condition and requirement of the licensing of any carnival or circus to show in the city, the applicant for such license shall pay to the city secretary a license fee in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.230), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-39. - Issuance of license. 
    Upon approval by the city council of an application for a license under this section, and payment of the fee prescribed, the code enforcement officer shall issue a license to the applicant to show and conduct the carnival or circus in the city. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.240), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-40. - Term of license. 
    A license issued under this section shall cover one (1) appearance in the city and shall be good only for as many days as the carnival or circus remains continuously in the city. A new license shall be required each time the carnival or circus returns to the city. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.250), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-41. - Operation under license. 
    Any person obtaining a license to show and conduct a carnival or circus within the city limits shall have the right to show, maintain, and operate only such shows, rides, booths, businesses and other attractions as shall be under the direct charge and supervision of the owner or operator of the carnival or circus, and it shall not be lawful for any person to show or conduct in connection with the carnival or circus, any show, attraction, ride, booth or concession of any kind or character independent of the carnival's or circus' ownership and management. The license granted to such carnival or circus covers and permits only such shows, attractions, rides, booths and concessions as are owned and operated by the person applying for the license. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.260), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-42. - Exemption. 
    This article shall not apply to any show or exhibition supported and sponsored by local operators for charitable and benevolent purposes-not for individual or personal profit to those managing and operating the same-regardless of whether such local show or exhibition shall have some of the features of a carnival or circus in connection with same, nor shall it apply to ferris wheel, merry-go-round ride and similar amusement devices sponsored by local merchants, service clubs, and other organizations, and not operated in connection with any show or exhibition. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.270), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-43. - License-Display. 
    Each applicant for a carnival or circus license will display the license at all times while engaging in business in the city. Upon request or demand of a peace officer, the licensee will exhibit the permit to indicate compliance with all of the relevant requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.280), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-44. - License-Non-transferability. 
    Licenses issued under the provisions of this article are not transferable in any situation and will be clearly marked "Not Transferable." 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.290), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-45. - License-Suspension. 
(a)  The chief of police or the chief's designee may, upon documented violation of law or endangerment of public welfare, health or safety by a carnival or circus, suspend and confiscate a license issued under this article. 
(b)  Carnivals or circuses whose licenses are suspended have three (3) business days during which to request an administrative review by the code enforcement officer of the suspension. If request for administrative review is not made within three (3) working days, the license is revoked. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.300), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-46. - License-Revocation. 
(a)  Upon a licensee's request, the code enforcement officer shall provide the licensee with written notice containing the particulars of any and all complaints against the licensee, and the time, date and place for an administrative review of the suspension. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer will conduct an administrative review to determine whether the license shall be restored or revoked. 
(c)  After notice and review, the code enforcement officer may revoke any license issued under this article for the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraudulent statements or omissions on a license application or in conduct of a licensed carnival or circus; 
(2)  Violation of law; 
(3)  Endangerment of public welfare, health or safety. 
(d)  If the code enforcement officer revokes a permit, the permittee may appeal the decision in writing to the planning and zoning commission. A subcommittee of the planning and zoning commission, composed of the chairman of the commission and two (2) members of the commission appointed by the chairman, shall decide whether to affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the code enforcement officer, by majority vote. If the subcommittee revokes a permit, the permit holder may appeal this decision in writing to the city council. The city council may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the subcommittee. 
(e)  Revocation of any license shall bar the licensee from eligibility for any license under this article for a period of one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.310), 12-6-04) 
Secs. 13-47-13-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POOL HALLS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Note- See the editor's note to Art. II of this chapter. 

Sec. 13-51. - Definition of terms. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the same meaning respectively ascribed to them: 
(1)  Billiard table shall mean any table surrounded by a ledge or cushion with or without pockets upon which balls are played with a stick or cue. 
(2)  Licensee shall mean any person holding a pool hall license issued under the provisions of this article. 
(3)  Pool hall shall mean any place which charges a fee for the use of one (1) or more billiard tables. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.410), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-52. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a pool hall between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on weekdays and Saturdays and between 1:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. on Sundays. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.420), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-53. - License. 
(a)  License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a pool hall within the city without first obtaining a license therefor from the code enforcement officer. 
(b)  Application for license. Each person, firm, company, association or corporation desiring to operate a pool hall in the city shall make an application in writing on a form provided by the city requesting a license for such pool hall. Each application for a license to operate a pool hall shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, age, sex, address, and telephone number of applicant and of the manager or officer in charge of the proposed pool hall; 
(2)  The location of the proposed pool hall; 
(3)  The number of persons to be employed by applicant, if any, and nature of such employment; 
(4)  A statement as to whether the applicant or manager or other officer in charge has ever been charged with, or convicted of, a felony, any violation of the liquor laws, any offense involving lewd or indecent conduct or narcotics, or any other misdemeanor (other than traffic violations) and full information concerning any convictions. 
(5)  A statement that any violation of state law, this article, or any other city ordinance which may occur at such establishment will be promptly reported to the police department. 
(6)  A statement that no person will be allowed to work or perform duties at such establishment who has been finally convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude or any offense involving immoral acts, lewd or indecent conduct, or narcotics. 
(c)  Making false statements. It shall be unlawful for any applicant for a license under the provisions of this section to make any false statements while making application therefor. 
(d)  Fee for license. The fee to be charged and collected for any license issued under the provisions of this section shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(e)  Denial of license. No license to operate a pool hall shall be issued under the provisions of this article if the applicant or manager or officer in charge: 
(1)  Has had a license revoked during the past one (1) year; 
(2)  Has had a license denied during the past one (1) year; 
(3)  Has been convicted of a felony, a crime involving moral turpitude or any offense involving immoral acts, lewd or indecent conduct, or narcotics; 
(4)  Has not maintained the premises to be used in accordance with the provisions of this article, state law, and other city ordinances, rules or regulations. 
(f)  Revocation or suspension. Any license issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked or suspended upon the violation by a licensee or any of his employees of any applicable provision of this section, state law, or other city ordinances, rules or regulations. 
(g)  Complaints. 
(1)  Any person may initiate proceedings for revocation or suspension of any license issued under the provisions of this article by filing a sworn complaint with the code enforcement officer alleging the commission of any act in violation of any applicable provision of this article, state law, or other city ordinances, rules or regulations. 
(2)  Upon the filing of any complaint alleging the violation of any applicable provision of this article, state law, or other city ordinances, rules or regulations by any person holding a license under the provisions of this section or any agent or employee of such person, the code enforcement officer shall give at least ten (10) days written notice to such licensee that a hearing will be held to determine whether or not such licensee's license shall be suspended or revoked. The date, time and place of the hearing shall be set forth in the notice. 
(3)  After hearing the evidence and testimony, the code enforcement officer shall determine whether or not the licensee has committed the violation alleged in the complaint. If he finds for the licensee, the complaint shall be dismissed. If he finds that the licensee is guilty of the violation, he shall either suspend the license for a period not to exceed twelve (12) months or revoke the license. 
(h)  Appeal of revocation or suspension. If the code enforcement officer suspends or revokes a permit, the permittee may appeal the decision in writing to the planning and zoning commission. A subcommittee of the planning and zoning commission, composed of the chairman of the commission and two (2) members of the commission appointed by the chairman, shall decide whether to affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the code enforcement officer, by majority vote. If the subcommittee suspends or revokes a permit, the permit holder may appeal this decision in writing to the city council. The city council may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the subcommittee. 
(i)  Display of license. All licenses issued under the provisions of this section shall be promptly displayed by the licensee at the subject pool hall. 
(j)  Inspection. Any pool hall within the city shall be subject to inspection by members of the police department and the code enforcement officer at any time. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.430), 12-6-04) 
Sec. 13-54. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article is guilty of a class C misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not more than allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-12-04, § II(13.440), 12-6-04) 
Secs. 13-55-13-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TAXICABS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II, adopted March 7, 2005, amended provisions formerly set out as Art. III, §§ 13-61-13-74, of this chapter in its entirety, which pertained to similar provisions as this Art. V, §§ 13-61-13-74, and derived from Ord. No. O-5-96, §§ I-XIV, adopted May 6, 1996. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion of the provisions of Ord. No. O-03B-05. 

Sec. 13-61. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Driver means an individual who drives or operates a taxicab. 
    Holder means a person who is granted an annual operating permit to operate a taxicab service under the provisions of this article. 
    Operate means to drive or be in control of a taxicab. 
    Operating permit means permission granted by the city to operate a taxicab service inside the city for a period of one (1) year, renewable under the provisions of this article. 
    Operator means the driver of a taxicab, the owner of a taxicab or the holder of an annual operating permit. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, agency, trust, partnership, or two (2) or more persons having a joint or common economic interest. 
    Taxicab means a private passenger for-hire vehicle used to transport persons for hire in vehicles designed for carrying no more than eight (8) passengers, on a call or demand basis, within the city limits of the municipality, or on property owned by the municipality, either singly or jointly with other municipalities or public agencies, or on property in which the municipality possesses an ownership interest, or from such municipality, municipal property, or municipal property interest and returning thereto, with the following exceptions: 
(1)  A vehicle being operated pursuant to a franchise or permit for the transportation by said vehicle of passengers for hire, legally issued by an authorized agency of the state, or a vehicle being operated as a chartered bus under a contract to carry nine (9) or more passengers; 
(2)  Vehicles being used as ambulances; 
(3)  Vehicles rented or leased for self operation by the person actually driving the same, unless such a vehicle is transporting for compensation persons other than the one who actually rented or leased the same. 
    Taxicab driver's license means a license issued to a person by the city authorizing that person to operate a taxicab in the city for a period of one (1) year from the date of its issuance. 
    Taxicab service means a passenger transportation service operated for hire that uses one (1) or more taxicabs in the operation of the service and includes, but is not limited to, a facility from which the service is operated, taxicabs used in the operation, and a person who owns, controls, or operates the service. 
    Taximeter means a device that automatically computes a taxi fare based upon the distance traveled or the time the taxicab is engaged or both. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.510), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-62. - Conduct of drivers. 
    While on duty, a taxicab driver shall conduct himself in a reasonable, prudent and courteous manner. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.511), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-63. - Inspection and qualification of taxicabs. 
    Before being allowed to operate upon the streets of the city, each taxicab shall be inspected and approved annually by the chief of police or his representative. No taxicab shall be driven or operated upon the streets of the city unless the same is in safe condition and free from mechanical defects, and it must further meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Have a current valid state inspection sticker and be in compliance with the safety requirements of the state motor vehicle code, as amended; and 
(2)  Be no more than five (5) years old; and 
(3)  Have a seat belt for each passenger; and 
(4)  Have an operating heater and air conditioner; and 
(5)  Have a two-way radio on the holder's dispatch frequency; and 
(6)  Have a current valid sticker issued by the city affixed to the windshield; and 
(7)  Have painted on both sides the trade name of the organization under whose operating permit such taxicab is being operated, the taxicab unit number, and the business telephone number of the holder of the operating permit. Such letters and numbers shall not be less than three (3) inches high with one-half-inch stroke, painted on each taxicab with permanent, nonwashable paint of a color sharply contrasting to the color of the taxicab so that the same will be readily apparent. Each holder of an operating permit for taxicab service in the city shall cause each taxicab to be painted in such a manner as to properly distinguish it from private vehicles and taxicabs operated by different taxicab services. The color combinations to be used shall be filed with the city secretary; and no two (2) such taxicab services shall be permitted to use the same or similar color combinations. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.512), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-64. - Taximeter. 
(a)  Every taxicab operating under an operating permit granted by the city shall have affixed thereto a taximeter which shall calculate fares in accordance with services rendered and rates established by the city council. 
(b)  The rates to be charged for taxicab service in the city shall be established by the city council as it may from time to time determine by resolution. 
(c)  Rates shall be posted inside the taxicab. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.513), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-65. - Refusal to convey passengers. 
(a)  While operating a taxicab, a driver shall not refuse to convey a person who requests service unless: 
(1)  The person is disorderly; or 
(2)  The driver is engaged in answering a previous request for service; or 
(3)  The driver is in fear of his personal safety. 
(b)  Except as specified in subsection (a) above, while operating a taxicab, a driver shall not refuse service requested by radio dispatcher when the location of the taxicab is within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.514), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-66. - Operating permit required. 
    No person shall drive, operate or cause to be operated, nor shall any person employ, permit or allow another to drive, operate or cause to be operated, any taxicab upon any street in the city for the purpose of transporting a passenger or passengers for compensation, nor shall any person accept compensation for transportation of passengers, without first having obtained from the city, under the provisions of this article, an operating permit authorizing such operation and acts, except a vehicle which is lawfully transporting a passenger or passengers from a point outside the city to a destination within the city, or, after discharging such passenger within the city, is returning empty by the most direct route to its regular place of business outside the city; provided, however, that no such vehicle without such operating permit shall solicit or accept a passenger or passengers from any point within the city for transportation to any destination whatsoever, and no such vehicle without such operating permit shall remain waiting for more than five (5) minutes at any point in the city for a passenger brought in by it for the purpose of continuing the journey of such passenger or for any purpose except to have repairs made upon it at a garage or other place where automobile repairs are customarily made. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.515), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-67. - Application for operating permit. 
(a)  To obtain a taxicab operating permit, a person shall file a written application with the city secretary in the manner prescribed by this section. That applicant must be the person who will own, control, or operate the proposed taxicab service. An applicant shall file with the city secretary a written verified application containing the following: 
(1)  The form of business of the applicant, if the business is a corporation or association, a copy of the documents establishing the business, and the name, address and citizenship of each person with a direct interest in the business; 
(2)  Name, address and verified signature of the applicant; 
(3)  An actual or pro forma income statement and balance sheet showing the assets, liabilities and the equity of the business; 
(4)  Description of any past business experience of the applicant, particularly in providing passenger transportation services, identification and description of any revocation or suspension of a license, franchise or permit held by the applicant or business before the date of filing the application; 
(5)  The number of vehicles and description of the vehicles the applicant proposes to use in the operation of the taxicab service; the description of the operations of the proposed taxicab services and the location of the fixed facilities to be used in the operation; 
(6)  The description of the proposed insignia and color scheme for the applicant's taxicabs; 
(7)  Documentary evidence from an insurance company, authorized to do business in the state, indicating a willingness to provide liability insurance required by this article; 
(8)  Documentary evidence of payment of ad valorem taxes on the property to be used in connection with the operation of the proposed taxicab service; 
(9)  A description of each felony or misdemeanor for which the applicant has ever been convicted, including the nature of the offense, the date of the offense, the date of conviction, the name and address of the convicting court, and the number and style of the criminal case; and 
(10)  Such additional information as the applicant desires to include to aid in the determination of whether the requested operating permit should be granted; and 
(11)  Such additional information as the city council considered necessary to assist or promote the implementation or enforcement of this article or the protection of the public safety. 
(b)  When an application for an operating permit containing the required information in full, properly verified, is filed with the city secretary, it shall be placed on the agenda of the city council for the next regular meeting of the city council following the filing of such application. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.516), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-68. - Investigation of application for operating permit by city council. 
(a)  After receiving any application for an operating permit, the city council shall make or cause to be made by its agents or employees, or by a person designated by it, such investigation as it may consider necessary. If such person has been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor, the application shall be considered in accordance with the section 13-73(5) hereof. The city council shall determine whether or not the public necessity and convenience require the operation of such taxicabs and whether or not the applicant is fit and proper, qualified and able to officially conduct such business and render such service to the public, but the operating permit will not be granted unless the holder of the operating permit: 
(1)  Provides taxicab service to the entire city with a minimum of one (1) taxicab registered to service; and 
(2)  Provides taxicab service between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., seven (7) days a week; and 
(3)  Provides dispatch service to taxicabs between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., seven (7) days a week; and 
(4)  Provides proof of minimum liability insurance for each taxicab as follows: 
a.  Bodily injury, two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) each person, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) each occurrence; and 
b.  Property damage, one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) each occurrence; and 
(5)  The holder of an operating permit pays an annual operating fee based on a rate as the city council may determine from time to time by resolution. 
(b)  An operating permit may not be granted for a period longer than one (1) year; however, the annual operating permit is automatically renewed; provided, however, the holder thereof is in full compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.517), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-69. - Public hearings on application for operating permit. 
    No permit to operate a taxicab service in the city shall be granted until a public hearing shall have been held before the city council on such request at a regular meeting of the city council. Upon approval of an application for a taxicab operating permit by the city council, the permit will be granted in the manner prescribed in this article, containing such terms or conditions as are included by the city council. Unless the permit expressly indicates otherwise, the provisions of this article are expressly set forth therein. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.518), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-70. - Transferability of operating permit. 
    An operating permit issued under the provisions of this article may not be transferred to another person unless such transfer is approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.519), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-71. - Revocation of operating permit. 
    The city council may revoke a taxicab operating permit if it determines that the holder has done any of the following: 
(1)  Failed to comply with any provisions of this article; 
(2)  Breached any of the terms of the operating permit; 
(3)  Failed to pay city ad valorem taxes on property having taxable situs in the city, used directly or indirectly in connection with the taxicab service; 
(4)  Failed to pay the annual permit fee when due. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.520), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-72. - Taxicab driver's license required. 
(a)  A person may not drive a taxicab inside the city unless he has a valid taxicab driver's license issued to him under the provisions of this article. 
(b)  A holder may not employ or contract with a driver or otherwise allow a person to drive for hire a taxicab owned, controlled, or operated by the holder unless the person has a valid taxicab driver's license issued to him under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.521), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-73. - Qualifications for taxicab driver's license. 
    To qualify for a taxicab driver's license, an applicant must: 
(1)  Be a legal resident of the United States; 
(2)  Hold a valid license issued by the state authorizing application to operate a taxicab; 
(3)  Be able to communicate in the English language; 
(4)  Not have been convicted of more than four (4) moving traffic violations arising out of separate transactions, nor involved in more than two (2) automobile accidents in which it could be reasonably determined that he was at fault, within a twelve-month period during the preceding thirty-six (36) months; 
(5)  Not have been convicted of any crime involving murder, theft, burglary, robbery, prostitution, promotion of prostitution, public lewdness, a sexual offense or a drug related offense, unless five (5) years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement, whichever is the later date. 
(6)  Not have been convicted of, or discharged by probation or deferred adjudication for, driving while intoxicated or under the influence of drugs; 
(7)  Have completed a defensive driving course approved by the National Safety Council within the last twelve (12) months prior to making his or her application for the license initially granted to the applicant; 
(8)  Pay a taxicab driver's license permit fee annually based on a rate as determined by the city council from time to time by resolution. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.522), 3-7-05) 
Sec. 13-74. - Revocation of taxicab driver's license. 
    The chief of police may revoke a taxicab driver's license if he determines that the licensee has failed to comply with any of the provisions of this article. The revocation of the taxicab driver's license is effective immediately upon notification in writing to the driver or the holder of the annual operating permit. The licensee may appeal the revocation to the city council within five (5) days of receipt of the notice of revocation of the taxicab driver's license. 
(Ord. No. O-03B-05, § II (13.523), 3-7-05) 
Secs. 13-75-13-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - REGISTRATION OF RETAIL ELECTRIC PROVIDERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-03-03, adopted March 24, 2003, enacted new provisions which in effect amended Art. VI of this chapter in its entirety. Former Art. VI, §§ 13-100-13-103, pertained to retail electric providers and derived from Ord. No. O-01D-02, § I, adopted Jan. 22, 2002. Sections 1-4 of Ord. No. O-03-03 have been included herein as a new Art. VI, §§ 13-100-13-103 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 13-100. - General provisions. 
(a)  Purpose. The City of Crockett City Council finds that it is in the best interest of the public to require that a retail electric provider (REP) register as a condition of serving city residents. This article establishes a "safe harbor" process for registration of REPs to standardize notice and filing procedures, deadlines, and registration information and fees. The "safe harbor" registration process provides certainty to city and REPs, thereby facilitating the development of a competitive retail electric market in Texas. 
(b)  Repeal of existing ordinance addressing REP registration. To the extent that an existing ordinance or ordinances of the City of Crockett address REP registration, such other ordinance or ordinances are hereby repealed. 
(c)  Definitions. The following words and terms, when used in this article, shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Commission or PUC shall mean the Public Utility Commission of Texas. 
    PURA shall mean the Texas Public Utility Regulatory Act, as amended. 
    REP shall mean retail electric provider. 
    Registration form shall mean the registration form approved by the commission in accordance with Commission Substantive Rule § 25.113 and available on the commission's website or from the commission's central records division. 
    Resident shall mean any electric customer located within the city, except the City of Crockett, regardless of customer class. 
    Revocation shall mean the cessation of all REP business operations within city, pursuant to commission order. 
    Suspension shall mean the cessation of all REP business operations within city associated with obtaining new customers, pursuant to commission order. 
(d)  Non-discrimination in REP registration requirements. The registration requirements apply equally to all REPs and types of REP. However, the city may exclude from its registration requirement the REP that provides service only to the city's own electric accounts as long as the REP providing service to the city does not serve any residents of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. O-03-03, § 1, 3-24-03) 
Sec. 13-101. - Registration. 
(a)  Standards for registration of REPs. Registrations will be processed administratively by city. 
(1)  A REP shall register within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this article or thirty (30) days after providing retail electric service to any resident of the city, whichever is later. 
(2)  A REP shall register with the city by completing the registration form approved by the commission, and signed by an owner, partner, officer, or other authorized representative of the registering party. Forms may be submitted to city by mail or facsimile. 
(3)  The city shall review the submitted registration form for completeness, including the remittance of the registration fee. Within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of an incomplete registration, the city shall notify the registering party in writing of the deficiencies in the registration. The registering party shall have twenty (20) business days from the issuance of the notification to cure the deficiencies. If the deficiencies are not cured within twenty (20) business days, the city shall notify the registering party that the registration is rejected without prejudice. 
(b)  Information. The city shall require a REP to provide only the information set forth in the registration form. 
(c)  Registration fees. REPs shall pay a reasonable administrative fee for the purpose of registration. 
(1)  Each retail electric provider required to register under this article shall pay to the city a one-time registration fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(2)  A REP shall pay a late fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) if the REP fails to register within thirty (30) days after this article requiring registration becomes effective or thirty (30) days after providing retail electric service to any resident of the municipality, whichever is later. 
(d)  Post-registration requirements and re-registration. 
(1)  A REP shall notify city within thirty (30) days of any change in information provided in its registration. In addition, a REP shall notify city within ten (10) days if it discontinues offering service to residents of city. 
(2)  If a REP's registration is revoked and the REP subsequently cures its defects and resumes operations it must re-register. In that circumstance, the REP may register in the same manner as a new REP. 
(Ord. No. O-03-03, § 2, 3-24-03) 
Sec. 13-102. - Suspension and revocation. 
    The city may suspend or revoke a REP's registration and authority to operate within the municipality upon a commission finding that the REP has committed significant violations of PURA Chapter 39 or rules adopted under that chapter. The city will not suspend or revoke the registration of the affiliated REP or provider of last resort (POLR) serving residents in the city.
