Sec. 17-79. - Street structural thickness design. 
(a)  Engineered design of street structural section. 
(1)  Except as provided by subsection (b) herein, the developer shall have a registered engineer design the street structural sections (structural thickness) in accordance with: 
a.  American Association of State Highway Officials (AASHO), Flexible-Pavement Design Method; 
b.  Asphalt Institute Design Method; 
c.  Portland Cement Association, Rigid Pavement Design Method; or 
d.  Any other design methods not specifically mentioned in this manual may be used with prior approval of the city. 
(2)  The street structural section design shall be based on the total number and weight (plus configuration) of the axles expected to go over the street section during a design life of twenty (20) years. The concept of "equivalent axle loadings" shall be used to express the total number and mixture of loadings that will occur during the street section's expected life. If a roadway is proposed, it will be designed as an arterial, collector, or local, and the street structural section design shall be based on the following loadings: 
Street Design Group Equivalent 18,000 lb. Axle Loads
(20-year design life) Std. arterial (A-1, A-2) collector or local in a medium or heavy Industrial area (C-1, L-1, L-3) 5,000,000 Collector or local in a light industrial or commercial area (C-1, L-1, L-3) 3,000,000 Std. collector (C-1, C-2, C-3) 400,000 Std. local (L-1, L-2, L-4, L-5) 9,000  
(b)  Standard structural section design for paved local streets. In lieu of a designed street structural section, the developer may design and construct local street pavement sections (see also section 17-79(a)(1) and (2)) as follows: 
(1)  11/2" hot-mix asphaltic concrete (H.M.A.C.), 7" flexible base, 6" stabilized subgrade; 
(2)  Two (2) course surface treatment; 
(3)  5" H.M.A.C., 6" stabilized subgrade; 
(4)  6" reinforced Portland Cement concrete (with 2" sand cushion permitted), 6" stabilized subgrade. 
(c)  Soils testing and subgrade stabilization. 
(1)  Prior to the construction of a street or streets, the developer shall submit to the city a soils test report for each one thousand (1,000) square yards of paved surface proposed or for each type of soil encountered in the subgrade. 
(2)  Prior to the construction of a street or streets, the developer shall submit to the city the following data as part of the soils test report: 
a.  Soil classification; 
b.  Optimum moisture/density (modified Proctor, ASTM D 1557); 
c.  Atterberg liquid limits and plasiticity index (P.I.); 
d.  Stabilization requirements for subgrade sole percent lime for clay or percent cement for sandy soils), if street structural section is to be designed by an engineer; 
e.  All tests shall be performed by a certified testing laboratory. 
(3)  The developer shall stabilize all subgrade soils with a P.I. of twenty (20) or more: 
a.  If the standard structural section design for paved local streets is used, five (5) percent lime by weight may be used; otherwise, 
b.  The developer shall have a certified testing laboratory conduct lime (or other approved material) series test to determine the percent of stabilizing agent necessary to lower the P.I. below twenty (20). 
(4)  Native soils with a P.I. of less than twenty (20) may be used as subgrade material as long as they can meet the city's compaction requirements (see below). The developer may add a stabilizing agent (lime, cement, etc.) as recommended by soils analysis, to such low P.I. soil to aid in compaction. 
(5)  Subgrade soils evaluation shall generally apply to the top six (6) inches of soil measured down from the proposed subgrade surface. 
(6)  Construction of a street or streets shall not be commenced until the written approval of the city engineer certifying compliance with this Ordinance No. O-9D-87 has been furnished to the city administrator and the developer. 
(d)  Other basic criteria. 
(1)  The developer shall compact all subgrade and individual layers of base and paving materials to ninety-five (95) percent relative density, modified Proctor test. 
(2)  The total design thickness of the street structural section shall be rounded up to the nearest whole inch. 
(3)  The total thickness of a asphaltic concrete pavement may be divided into different grades of material. Unless otherwise approved by the city, type "D" hot-mix asphaltic concrete (H.M.A.C.), per Item 340, Texas State Department of Highways and Public Transportation Standard Specifications, shall be used for a surface course. 
(4)  The developer shall lay asphalt concrete pavement in lifts no more than three (3) nor less than one and one-half inches each, unless otherwise approved by the city. 
(5)  The developer shall completely clear and grub the area within ten (10) feet behind the proposed curbs or edge of pavement prior to construction of any street improvements. 
(6)  The design requirements set forth in this chapter are minimum design standards. The city reserved the right to require additional precautions or treatments consistent with sound engineering practice to provide for conditions not specifically covered herein. 
(e)  Reserve areas of twenty-five (25) acres or less. The provisions of this section shall not apply to reserve areas of twenty-five (25) acres, or less, of subdivisions previously platted and filed with the Houston County Clerk; provided, however, that streets in such subdivision of reserve areas shall be built to same standard as the other streets in said subdivisions. 
(f)  Private streets and alleys. The developer shall design and construct private streets and alleys in accordance with this section. Private streets shall be used only within unified developments. 
(g)  Layout. The developer shall design private streets to: 
(1)  Provide adequate vehicular access to all buildings and facilities within the plat boundaries; 
(2)  Provide adequate interior traffic circulation and access to all buildings containing dwelling units by fire-fighting personnel and equipment; 
(3)  Allow for the smooth flow of vehicular traffic, avoiding such traffic hazards as closely offset intersections; and 
(4)  Provide direct access to the existing public street system adjacent to the tract boundaries. 
(h)  Width. The minimum unobstructed width of any private street shall not be less than twenty-four (24) feet. If parking is proposed along the private street, the developer shall widen the street to accommodate such parking. 
(i)  Culs-de-sac and dead-ends. Cul-de-sac and dead-end private streets shall be terminated by a circular turnaround having a paving radius of not less than forty (40) feet. 
(j)  Intersections of private streets with public streets. 
(1)  Private streets shall not be direct (straight line) projections of any public street. The private street shall offset a minimum distance of one hundred twenty-five (125) feet centerline to centerline from any public street intersection. Intersections of all private streets with public streets shall be at right angles with variations not to exceed fifteen (15) degrees. Right-angle intersections of private streets shall have a twenty-foot radii for the pavement edge at all corners. Acute angle intersections shall have twenty-five-foot radii for the pavement edge at the acute corner on both public and private streets. 
(2)  Except for pavement width, the portion of a private street within public street right-of-way, at its intersection with the public street, shall be designed and constructed by the developer in accordance with city standards. 
(k)  Access. The developer shall provide a street system within the development with at least one (1) point of access to a public street adjacent to the development; provided, however, that developments containing one hundred and fifty (150) dwelling units or more shall provide at least two (2) points of access to adjacent public streets. Private streets shall serve only the land within each development. The developer shall not extend private streets into adjacent tracts under a different ownership or a different property owners' association. 
(l)  Maintenance. Maintenance of private streets shall be the responsibility of property owners within the development. The property owners shall be legally bound together by deed restriction, contract, property owners' association, corporation or other organization that has as one of its purposes the continued care and maintenance of all commonly owned property within the development, including the private streets. 
(m)  Geometric and pavement designs. The developer shall design and construct private streets according to the standards established for local public streets. (See section 17-79). 
(Ord. No. O-9D-87, § 1, 9-21-87) 
Sec. 17-80. - Street names. 
(a)  Public street names. The developer shall name public streets in conformance with the following considerations: 
(1)  Names of new streets, not extensions of existing streets, shall not duplicate any existing street name in the City of Crockett. 
(2)  If a new street is a direct or logical extension of an existing street, existing street names shall be used. 
(3)  Street name suffixes such as "place," "court," "circle" and "loop" shall be designated on streets that are cul-de-sac or loop streets. Suffixes such as "Boulevard," "Parkway," "Expressway" and "Drive" shall be confined to designated arterial or collector streets. Suffixes such as "Highway" or "Freeway" shall be used only on designated highways or freeways falling under the jurisdiction of the Texas State Department of Highways and Public Transportation. 
(4)  Street name prefixes such as "North," "South," "East" and "West" may be used to clarify the general location of the street; however, such prefixes shall be consistent with the existing and established street naming and address numbering system of the general area in which the street is located. Streets running north and south are designated as streets, while those running east and west are designated as avenues. 
(5)  Alphabetical and numerical street names shall not be designated on any development plan unless the street is a direct extension of an existing street with that name. 
(6)  Street names shall fit in with the names of existing streets in the area. 
(b)  Private street names. 
(1)  Private street names shall conform to the same standards applicable to public street names and the following additional criteria: 
a.  The developer shall provide signs for all private streets; the signs shall conform in size, height and material to city standards. 
b.  The suffix "Private" shall be a part of all names established for private streets and such word shall be an integral part of any street sign. (Example of sign lettering: "SCENIC LN. PRIVATE"). 
c.  The background color for any private street sign shall be blue. 
(2)  No private street name shall be changed without approval of the city. 
(3)  Upon the establishment of the name of any private street under the terms and conditions of this article and the erection of signs, the owners of the property adjacent to such private street or a property owners' association shall be responsible for the continued maintenance of the private street signs. No private street sign shall be installed without the approval of the city. 
(4)  Private street signs not established in conformance with the provisions of this section and installed within the right-of-way of any public street may be removed from the public street right-of-way without notice. 
(Ord. No. O-9D-87, § 1, 9-21-87) 
Secs. 17-81-17-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 17-91. - Streets and drainage. 
    The subdivider shall improve all streets in the subdivision. Improvements shall be installed to a permanent line and grade to the satisfaction of the city administrator. All street construction work shall be performed by a bonded contractor who has filed a faithful performance bond with the city. Approval of the plat shall not impose any duty upon the city concerning the maintenance of the improvements until the city shall have made actual acceptance of the same. The minimum improvements which the subdivider shall make, or agree to make, prior to acceptance and approval of the final plat by the planning and zoning commission shall be: 
(1)  Grading, drainage and drainage structures necessary to properly drain the area. 
(2)  Pavement of a width suitable for the traffic on the street. 
(3)  Curb and gutter constructed of twenty-five hundred (2500) pounds per square inch concrete. 
(Ord. of 10-9-61, § 7) 
Sec. 17-92. - Utilities. 
    The minimum improvements which the subdivider shall make, or agree to make, prior to acceptance and approval of the final plat by the city council shall be: 
(1)  Water systems with mains of sufficient site and having a sufficient number of outlets to furnish an adequate domestic water supply, furnish fire protection to all lots and to meet the other requirements of the city. 
(2)  Sanitary sewer facilities to service the subdivision and meet the other requirements of the city. 
(3)  All services for utilities to be made available for each lot in such a manner as will obviate the necessity for disturbing the street paving, gutter, curb and drainage structures when connections are made. 
(Ord. of 10-9-61, § 7) 
Chapter 18 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Taxation generally, § 6.04 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Tax on sale and use of electricity and gas. 
(a)  The tax heretofore imposed by the city pursuant to the provisions of the Local Sales and Use Tax Act is hereby continued on the sale, production, distribution, lease or rental of and the use, storage or other consumption of gas and electricity for residential use. 
(b)  The sale, production, distribution, lease or rental of and the use, storage or other consumption of gas and electricity for residential use shall not be exempt from the tax imposed by the city under the Local Sales and Use Tax Act. 
(Ord. No. D-8, §§ 1, 2, 9-5-78) 
Sec. 18-2. - Penalty to defray attorney's fees in collection of ad valorem taxes. 
    The ad valorem taxes that remain delinquent on the first day of July of any year in which they become delinquent shall incur an additional penalty to defray costs of collection, said penalty to be in the amount of fifteen (15) percent of the amount of the taxes, penalty and interest due the city, which fee shall be an authorized collection expense. 
(Ord. No. O-4-82, § 1, 4-19-82) 
Sec. 18-3. - Real and personal property tax certificates. 
    For every real and personal property tax certificate issued by the City of Crockett, there shall be levied a charge in the amount of eight dollars ($8.00). (The previous charge has been four dollars ($4.00).) This amount is to be charged to the abstract company or any other members of the general public desiring tax certificates. 
(Ord. No. O-8A-87, § 1, 8-3-87) 
Secs. 18-4-18-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESIDENT HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to so provide, V.T.C.A. Tax Code, § 11.13. 

Sec. 18-16. - Granted. 
    From and after the first day of January, 1973, three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) of the assessed value of residence homesteads of persons who have attained the age of sixty-five (65) years or older on or before the first day of January of any year shall be exempt from all taxation for all city purposes for that year; provided however, that where the ad valorem tax has heretofore been pledged for the payment of any debt, the taxing officers of the city shall have authority to continue to levy and collect the tax against the homestead property at the same rate as the tax so pledged until the debt is discharged, if the cessation of the tax levy would legally void the obligation of the contract by which the debt was created. 
(Ord. No. A-12-72, § 1, 12-18-72) 
Sec. 18-17. - Filing; proof of age. 
    In order to secure the benefit of the resident homestead exemption, the property owner shall, between the first day of January and the first day of April of each year, file with the city tax assessor and collector a sworn inventory of the property owned on the first day of January of each year for which the exemption is claimed, and shall initially furnish proof of age by a certified copy of his birth certificate or, if such person does not have a certificate of birth, or is unable to secure such certificate, then by an affidavit satisfactory to the city tax assessor and collector. 
(Ord. No. A-12-72, § 2, 12-18-72) 
Secs. 18-18-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Hotel occupancy tax, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1266j, §§ 3a, 3b. 

Sec. 18-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consideration shall mean the cost of the room in a hotel and shall not include the costs of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant of the room, not related to the cleaning and readying of such room for occupancy, and shall not include any tax assessed for occupancy thereof by any other governmental agency. 
    Hotel shall mean any building or buildings, trailer or other facility in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations. The term shall include hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, rooming houses, trailer houses or other buildings where rooms are furnished for a consideration, but "hotel" shall not be defined so as to include hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes. 
    Occupancy shall mean the use or possession, or the rights to the use or possession of any room or rooms in a hotel for any purpose. 
    Occupant shall mean anyone who, for a consideration, uses, possesses or has a right to use or possess any room or rooms in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license contract or agreement. 
    Quarterly period shall mean the regular calendar quarters of the year, the first quarter being composed of the months of January, February and March, the second quarter being the months of April, May and June, and the third quarter being the months of July, August and September, and the fourth quarter being the months of October, November and December. 
    Permanent resident shall mean any occupant who has or shall have the right to occupancy of any room or rooms in a hotel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days during the current calendar year or preceding year. 
(Ord. No. O-10B-79, § 2, 10-1-79) 
Sec. 18-32. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to finance the general promotional and tourist advertising for the city and for such further purposes authorized by law for the expenditure of the funds generated by the tax. 
(Ord. No. O-10B-79, § 3, 10-1-79) 
Sec. 18-33. - Tax levied; rate. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a tax upon the occupancy of any room or space furnished by any hotel or motel where the cost of occupancy is at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) or more per day. 
(b)  The tax levied by subsection (a) shall be equal to seven (7) percent of the consideration paid by the occupant of the room or space to the hotel or motel. 
(Ord. No. O-10B-79, § 1, 10-1-79; Ord. No. O-8-81, § 1, 8-3-81; Ord. No. O-7B-86, §§ 1, 2, 7-7-86) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. O-7B-86, adopted July 7, 1986, raised the tax rate in § 18-33(b) from four (4) percent to seven (7) percent. Section 3 of said ordinance set out the following limitation: "The additional three (3) percent of revenue shall be used only for the retirement of negotiable revenue bonds and the acquisition of sites for and the construction, improvement, enlarging, equipping, repairing, operation, and maintenance of convention center facilities including, but not limited to, civic center convention buildings, auditoriums, and parking areas or facilities for the parking or storage of motor vehicles or other conveyances located at or in the immediate vicinity of the civic center convention facilities." 
Sec. 18-34. - Exceptions. 
    The tax imposed by section 18-33 shall not be imposed upon: 
(1)  A permanent resident of the city. 
(2)  A corporation or association organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes, in which no part of the net earnings inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
(Ord. No. O-10B-79, § 1, 10-1-79) 
Sec. 18-35. - Duty of operators to collect tax. 
    Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any motel or hotel within the city shall collect the tax imposed by section 18-33. 
(Ord. No. O-10B-79, § 4, 10-1-79) 
Sec. 18-36. - Quarterly report; payment of tax. 
    On the last day of the month following each quarterly period, every person required by section 18-35 to collect the tax imposed by this article shall file a report with the city secretary showing the consideration paid for all room occupancies in the preceding quarter, the amount of the tax collected on the occupancies, and other information as the city secretary may reasonably require. The requirements of this section may be met by submitting a copy of the state hotel-motel occupancy tax quarterly report and any amendment thereto to the city secretary. Such person shall pay the tax due on such occupancies at the time of filing such report. 
(Ord. No. O-10B-79, § 5, 10-1-79) 
Sec. 18-37. - Power of city secretary to establish rules, examine books. 
    The city secretary shall have the power to establish such rules and regulations as are necessary to effectively collect the tax levied by this article, and shall, upon reasonable notice, have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this article and the amount of taxes due under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-10B-79, § 6, 10-1-79) 
Sec. 18-38. - Agency for administration. 
    The city shall enter into a contract with an agency outside of the city government to administer the funds made available under this article and to carry out the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-10B-79, § 7, 10-1-79) 
Sec. 18-39. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  If any person shall fail to collect the tax imposed by section 18-33, or shall fail to file a report as required by section 18-36, or shall fail to pay to the city secretary the tax, as required by section 18-36, when said report or payment is due, or shall file a false report, then such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and be subject to the penalty prescribed by section 1-11. 
(b)  In addition to the penalty prescribed by subsection (a), any person who fails to remit the tax or violates the reporting provisions imposed by this article within the time required shall forfeit an additional five (5) percent of such tax; however, the penalty shall never be less than one dollar ($1.00). Delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the rate of six (6) percent per annum beginning sixty (60) days from the date due. 
(Ord, No. O-10B-79, § 8, 10-1-79) 
Sec. 18-40. - Tax collection; concurrent state tax delinquency. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, the City of Crockett adopts all of the provisions of V.T.C.A. Tax Code ch. 351, subch. A. 
(Ord. No. O-04-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Chapter 19 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Department of public utilities, §§ 5.02, 13.01 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-12-84, §§ 3.01-3.05, adopted Dec. 17, 1984, not expressly amendatory of the Code, has been included herein as §§ 19-14-19-18 of Art. I, at the discretion of the editor. 

Secs. 19-1-19-13. - Reserved. 
Sec. 19-14. - Service outside city limits. 
    Hereafter the policy of the city is that water and sewer service shall be extended outside the city limits as follows: 
The city shall not permit and will not undertake the construction and/or extension of water and/or sewer mains and pipes outside the corporate city limits of the City of Crockett, Texas except in the exclusive judgment of the city council such is found to be in the best interest of the citizens of the City of Crockett, Texas. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 3.01, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 19-15. - Liability for materials; exceptions. 
    Each property owner or subdivider shall furnish materials and shall install all water service lines and sanitary sewer laterals from the mains to the structures at his own cost and expense to meet the standard details and specifications and the approval of the city, except that the city will furnish the meters, necessary fittings, and meter boxes for the water service lines and will complete the meter installations and connections; provided, however, in order to promote state or local economic development and to stimulate business and commercial activity in the city, under the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 380.001, as now in effect and from time to time amended, the city council, by a majority vote of those present at the meeting, may direct the city to install water service lines and sanitary sewer laterals from mains to structures and provide the materials therefor, at total or partial city expense. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 3.02, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-4-96, § I, 4-15-96) 
Sec. 19-16. - Payment of bills. 
(a)  The rates and charges fixed and prescribed for the waterworks and sanitary systems shall be paid to the city simultaneously by users or customers on the billing date shown on the monthly statement, which shall be the date such rates or charges shall become due or payable unless otherwise indicated. The city shall refuse to accept the payment for a part of such service unless the entire amount due from the respective user or customer of all services supplied and billed is paid. All water, sewer, and garbage service billings to the customer not paid within fourteen (14) days of the billing date shall incur an additional penalty of fifteen (15) percent, and the customer will be sent a termination notice giving the customer ten (10) days from the date of the notice to pay the full balance, including penalty, in order to prevent disconnection of services for nonpayment. 
(b)  If disconnected for nonpayment, no customer shall be reconnected to city water services until payment is received for all past due bills, plus the penalty and a reconnection charge. The reconnection charge for first or second time reconnection will be fifty dollars ($50.00). For third, and all subsequent reconnections, the penalty will be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). All customers, with the exclusion of those who qualify for temporary water service under subsection 19-46(a), are billed for water, sewer, and garbage on their bill after requesting service unless any portion of the three (3) services is not available. The customers will not be billed for services not available. 
(c)  Any payment made by check will be subject to a thirty dollar ($30.00) service charge for each time a check is returned by the bank for any reason. Any delinquent account paid by a check that is returned by the bank shall be subject to immediate disconnection of service. To reinstate service, full restitution must be received for the check, applicable service charges, and a seventy-five dollar ($75.00) reconnection charge. Cash may be required for payment on any account that has had payment by check returned by the bank in the past. 
(d)  The additional penalty of fifteen (15) percent for late payment of charges for water, sewer and garbage service shall not apply to persons sixty-five (65) years of age or over. In order to claim this exemption, a person must make application at the city water office and furnish proof of age. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 3.03, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-10-86, § 1, 10-16-86; Ord. No. O-11-86, § 2, 11-3-86; Ord. No. O-9-99, § I, 9-20-99; Ord. No. O-4A-00, § I, 4-17-00; Ord. No. O-09E-05, § I, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 19-17. - Transfer account. 
(a)  Any person, corporation, partnership, limited liability company or other entity who owes any amount of money to the city for water or sewer fees or both shall not be permitted a water or sewer connection at any premises which the delinquent debtor subsequently purchases, owns, leases, rents or otherwise occupies until all delinquencies have been paid in full. Further, any person, corporation, partnership, limited liability company or other entity be found to be purchasing, owning, leasing, renting or otherwise occupying any premises and owing any amount of delinquent water or sewer fees or both to the City of Crockett shall have the water and sewer connections immediately disconnected to all premises so purchased, owned, rented, leased or otherwise occupied until all delinquencies are paid in full. 
(b)  If disconnected or terminated for nonpayment, no customer shall be reconnected to city water or sewer services until payment is received for all past due bills, plus the penalty and reconnection charge. The charge for first or second reconnection will be fifty dollars ($50.00). For third, and all subsequent, reconnections the charge will be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(c)  Any payment made by check will be subject to a thirty dollar ($30.00) service charge each time a check is returned by the bank for any reason. Any delinquent account paid by a check that is returned by the bank shall be subject to immediate disconnection of service. To reinstate service, full restitution must be received for the check, applicable service charges, and the applicable penalty and reconnection charge. Cash may be required for payment on any account that has had payment by check returned by the bank in the past. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 3.04, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-02-16 , § I, 2-22-16) 
Sec. 19-18. - No free service. 
    No free service shall be allowed, and, to the extent that the city or any of its departments avail themselves of the services and facilities afforded by the waterworks and sanitary sewer systems, they shall pay therefor the same rates and charges herein prescribed for other customers. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 3.05, 12-17-84) 
Secs. 19-19, 19-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Stagnant water declared a nuisance, § 11-16. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 19-21. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons to do, commit, or assist in committing any of the following acts in the city: 
(1)  Opening, closing hydrants, valves, etc. To open or close any fire hydrant, stopcock or other water fixture connected with the waterworks system of the city, or life or remove the covers of any gate valves or shutoffs thereof, without the permission of the public works director, except in case of fire, and then under the direction of officers of the fire department. 
(2)  Interfering with, destroying waterworks equipment. To interfere with, destroy, deface, impair, injure or wantonly force open any gate, or door, or in any way whatsoever destroy, injure, or deface any part of any engine house, reservoir, standpipe, elevated tank, buildings or appurtenances, fences, trees, shrubs or fixtures or property pertaining to the waterworks system. 
(3)  Climbing on water tanks or standpipes. To go upon or ascend the stairway or steps on any elevated water tank or standpipe of the waterworks system, except by permission of the director of public works. 
(4)  Obstructions near fire hydrants. To place any telegraph, telephone or electric pole or any obstruction whatsoever within three (3) feet of any fire hydrant. 
(5)  Use of fraudulent devices. To resort to any fraudulent device or arrangement for the purpose of procuring water for himself or others from private connections or premises contrary to the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(6)  Injuring tanks, hydrants, etc. To interfere with or injure any reservoir, tank, fountain, hydrant, pipe, cock, value or other apparatus pertaining to the waterworks system, or to hitch or tie any animal thereto. 
(7)  Using water without permit. To make or permit to be made any connection with the main or service pipes of the waterworks system or to turn on or use the water of the system without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(8)  Concealing valve boxes, etc. To cover or conceal from view any water valve box, service or meter box. 
(9)  Removing, tampering with meters. To remove any water meter that has been placed by the city, or to in any manner change, interfere with or tamper with any water meter; provided, that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to the employees of the city when acting in their official capacity. 
(10)  Turning on disconnected water supply. To turn on the water supply of any building or to any supply pipe where the supply has been turned off for the nonpayment of the monthly water charge or for the violation of any rule or ordinance governing the waterworks system. 
(Ord. No. D-7, § 1, 7-17-78) 
Sec. 19-22. - Meters to be set by city; separate meters required. 
(a)  All meters whether private or belonging to the waterworks system shall be set by the employees of the city. If the meter fails to register, the consumer will be charged at the average daily consumption as shown by the meter when in order. All water that passes through the meter shall be charged for, whether used or not. 
(b)  Each consumer of water living in a separate house must have a separate connection and meter for each house; where a residence is not in reach of a city water main, arrangements may be made, at the option of the city, to secure water from another user of city water. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, §§ 1.06, 1.07, 12-17-84) 
Editor's note- Sections 1.06 and 1.07 of Ord. No. O-12-84, adopted Dec. 17, 1984, have been treated by the editor as superseding the provisions of § 19-22, which pertained to the position and number of meters and was derived from Code 1960, § 11-1-7. 
Sec. 19-23. - Certain water cooling systems prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or allow to be used, water drawn from or flowing directly or indirectly, from the water mains of the city as a cooling agent in any type of cooler or cooling system rated at more than two thousand (2,000) c.f.m. for the purpose of regulating the temperature of the air, unless such cooler or cooling system collects such water and recirculates it after use by means of a lift pump or similar device. 
(Code 1960, § 11-1-9) 
Sec. 19-24. - Water leaks to be reported. 
    It shall be the duty of all employees of the city, including officers and members of the police force to report to the director of water utilities, upon blanks furnished for that purpose, any leaks or unnecessary waste of water that may come to their attention; also, any violation of Ordinance No. O-12-84 shall be noted. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.05, 12-17-84) 
Editor's note- Sections 1.05, 1.08 and 1.11 of Ord. No. O-12-84, adopted Dec. 17, 1984, not specifically amendatory of the Code, have been included herein as §§ 19-24-19-26, at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 19-25. - Repair of water lines. 
    In the interest of water conservation, if at any time, water lines and connections from the meter loop connection into the residence, house, barn, business, yard, or similar places become rusted out, broken or, in general, deteriorated, it shall be the duty of the owner of the premises to place his lines in a good and serviceable condition. The replaced and repaired lines must meet specifications laid down by the city plumbing code. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.08, 12-17-84) 
Editor's note- See the editor's note following § 19-24. 
Sec. 19-26. - Water rationing. 
    The mayor, or in his absence, the mayor pro-tem, of the city, may, when necessary to do so to protect the citizens of the city, order a rationing system suited to the emergency then existing, by declaring an emergency. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.11, 12-17-84) 
Editor's note- See the editor's note following § 19-24. 
Sec. 19-27. - Water conservation and emergency water demand management plan. 
(a)  The city council adopts the water conservation and drought contingency plans attached to Ordinance No. O-04-14, on file with the city. All ordinances that are in conflict with the provisions of Ordinance No. O-04-14 are hereby repealed. 
(b)  The city administrator or chief administrative officer or their designee, is hereby directed to file a copy of the plan and the ordinance codified in this section with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality in accordance with Title 30, Chapter 288 of the Texas Administrative Code and with Texas Water Development Board in accordance with Title 31, Chapter 363 of the Texas Administrative Code. 
(Ord. No. O-04-14, §§ 2, 5, 4-28-14) 
Secs. 19-28-19-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES AND CHARGES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1.01-1.04, 1.09, 1.10, 1.12-1.14 of Ord. No. O-12-84, adopted Dec. 17, 1984, have been treated by the editor as superseding the provisions of Div. 2 with the exception of § 19-42. Former Div. 2, §§ 19-36-19-41, pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from: Code 1960, §§ 11-1-1, 11-1-2, 11-1-4-11-1-6; Ord. No. O-10-82, § 4, 10-4-82; Ord. No. O-4-83, 4-18-83; and Ord. No. O-8-84, §§ 1, 4, 8-23-84. See also §§ 19-14-19-18. 

Sec. 19-36. - Application for connection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection to the mains or pipes of the waterworks system without first making application to the city, stating fully the several and various uses for which water is wanted, giving the name of the property, the number of the lot and block name of the street and house number. Upon the payment of the tapping fee, the director of water utilities shall make, or have made, the necessary connections and furnish a curb stop box and curb cock and connected with any water main, or being supplied with any water from the waterworks system, shall have a separate service connection, curb stop box and curb cock installed by and at the expense of the owner of the premises. If the application is approved by the director of water utilities, a permit will be issued. All fees and charges shall be paid for at amounts and rates fixed by applicable sections of this article. 
    A customer applying for new service has to make application with the city water office before putting up their deposit and has to be eighteen (18) years or older. If a person making application in either the husband's name or wife's name (or wife's previous name) owes an old bill in either name or names to the city, the old bills will have to be paid before the application is approved. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.01, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 19-37. - Water rates. 
(a)  The monthly rates or charges for service furnished by the city's water works system inside the city limits shall be as follows: 
(1)  The rates for residential water shall be twenty-four dollars and sixty-seven cents ($24.67) minimum for the first two thousand (2,000) gallons and four dollars and eighty-nine cents ($4.89) per one thousand (1,000) for anything over two thousand (2,000) gallons. 
(2)  The rates for commercial water shall be thirty-four dollars and seventy-one cents ($34.71) minimum for the first two thousand (2,000) gallons and four dollars and eighty-nine cents ($4.89) per one thousand (1,000) for anything over two thousand (2,000) gallons. 
(3)  Rates for water service outside the city limits shall be two (2) times those inside the city limits. 
(b)  Where there is more than one (1) residential unit (including apartments), business, mobile home, or trailer connected to one (1) meter, the minimum charge for water-sewer-garbage will be assessed for each of the units served by the meter. Any additional amount the meter registers above the minimums on water shall be charged accordingly. The sewer charge will be likewise increased. 
(c)  Water meters. 
(1)  Water meters shall be installed at the request of the owner of the improvements or the real property (hereinafter called the "property owner"), as the case may be. If the property involved is a detached entity having open space on all exterior walls or an apartment or duplex complex, the water meters can be titled in the name of the lessee. Each detached entity shall have its own meter. All other water meters shall be titled in the name of the property owner. The property owner shall pay for the installation of the water meters and for all water that flows through the water meters in the property owner's name. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the property owner if more than one (1) residential unit (including apartments), business, mobile home, trailer is connected to a water meter to: 
a.  Notify the city water department before the connection is made; and 
b.  Collect a minimum charge for water-sewer-garbage from each occupier of an additional residential unit (including apartments), business, mobile home, or trailer. The property owner shall also collect for any additional amount the meter registers above the minimum on water and sewer. 
(3)  Payment for water shall be the responsibility of the property owner, and the city will look to the property owner for such payment. The property owner will be billed for all water flowing through meters in his name. The occupier of the extra residential units, business mobile home or trailer will not be billed. 
(d)  This section shall be retroactive and shall apply to all persons presently using water meters. 
(e)  Definition of unit. A unit for water and sewer purposes is a unit that contains within itself connections for and fixtures used for water and sewer. A space occupied by lessee is not a unit if the water and sewer facilities are used in common by all the lessees. 
(f)  Bulk water sales. 
(1)  The City of Crockett shall be allowed to sell bulk water to customers at the following rates: A basic service charge of four hundred dollars ($400.00) and an additional nineteen dollars ($19.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
(2)  Whenever a city employee is required to dispense the water to a purchaser of bulk water, an additional service charge of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be assessed against the purchaser. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.02, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-2-86, § 1, 2-3-86; Ord. No. O-7A-86, § 1, 7-7-86; Ord. No. O-10-86, § 2, 10-6-86; Ord. No. O-9B-87, § 1, 9-8-87; Ord. No. O-10A-87, §§ 1-3, 10-19-87; Ord. No. O-2-89, Arts. I, II, 2-20-89; Ord. No. O-11-89, §§ 1, 2, 11-6-89; Ord. No. O-9D-91, §§ 1, 2, 9-16-91; Ord. No. O-9C-97, §§ 1, 2, 9-15-97; Ord. No. O-9-99, §§ II, III, 9-20-99; Ord. No. O-09E-05, § I, 9-6-05; Ord. No. O-09C-07, § I, 9-4-07; Ord. No. O-09C-08, § I, 9-2-08; Ord. No. O-09G-10, § I, 9-7-10; Ord. No. O-09B-12, § I, 9-4-12; Ord. No. O-09B-13, § I, 9-9-13; Ord. No. O-08C-14, § I, 8-18-14; Ord. No. O-08C-16 , § I, 8-15-16) 
Sec. 19-38. - Tapping city mains. 
(a)  The tapping fees for connection to the waterworks system shall be the following, plus a meter deposit: 
Size of Connection (in inches) Fee 3/4 $400.00 1 $400.00 plus the difference in cost between a 3/4" meter and a 1" meter 2 $700.00 plus the difference in cost between a 3/4" meter and a 2" meter 4 The total cost of materials, labor and equipment 6 The total cost of materials, labor and equipment Larger than 6 To be set by council  
(b)  If the tap requires a road bore, there shall be added to the fee the cost charged by the road boring contractor, plus fifteen (15) percent of that cost. 
(c)  If the tapping requires an open cut road, there shall be an additional charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per foot of open cut, plus additional charges if special equipment or materials are required to meet state highway requirements. 
(d)  Hot tap fees will be based on the total cost of materials, labor and equipment. 
(e)  In the case of apartment complexes, mobile home parks, office buildings, motels, townhouses, multifamily dwellings, and all other facilities other than single-family dwellings served by one (1) master meter; the charges shall be: 
(1)  Mobile home parks: Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each mobile home space plus the total cost of materials and labor for the master meter. 
(2)  Apartment complexes, townhouses, office buildings, multifamily dwellings and similar structures served by one (1) master meter: 
a.  Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each unit as shown on the plans submitted for a building permit plus the total cost of materials and labor. 
b.  Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each separate place of business as shown on the plans submitted for a building permit plus the total cost of materials and labor. 
(f)  Taps outside the city limits shall be one and one-half (11/2) times those charges within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.03, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-11-91, § I, 11-18-91; Ord. No. O-10B-02, § I, 10-7-02; Ord. No. O-09C-07, § II, 9-4-07; Ord. No. O-09G-10, § II, 9-7-10) 
Sec. 19-39. - Discontinuance of service. 
    Any person wishing to discontinue the use of water supplied from the waterworks system must give notice hereof to the city; otherwise, the charge for service will be continued until such notice has been given. No charge will be made for shutting off such service. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.04, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 19-40. - Meter deposit. 
(a)  Each water consumer shall make a meter deposit in at least the following amounts when service is applied for: 
Residential ..... $150.00 
Commercial ..... 200.00 
(b)  Additional deposits may be required. 
(1)  Should the deposit amount be insufficient to pay an average monthly bill, or if experience has proven that a consumer does not pay water bills promptly and as due, or if a new consumer applying for service cannot show sufficient financial ability to be able to pay future billings, the city administrator may require the meter deposit to be in any sum he or she deems necessary to protect the city from unpaid water and sewer bills. 
(2)  The meter deposit may be applied to the payment of any water and sewer charges overdue to the city. Any unused portion of the deposit shall be refunded to the consumer at the time service is discontinued. 
(c)  Each water consumer who does not have an ownership interest in the premises for which a water meter is requested must, at the time application is made for a water meter, furnish a copy of a fully executed lease or rental agreement or written verification of the rental signed by the property owner. Water service will be provided only to the tenant designated on the lease or rental agreement or in the written verification. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.09, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-10-86, § 3, 10-6-86; Ord. No. O-1A-99, § II, 1-20-99; Ord. No. O-4-00, § I, 4-17-00; Ord. No. O-09E-05, § III, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 19-41. - New service at existing connections. 
    A charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00) will be made for turning on a new water service where a water connection, including tap and meter, already exists. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.10, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-09E-05, § IV, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 19-42. - Place of payment. 
    All water accounts shall be payable at the city hall to the person designated by the city administrator. 
(Code 1960, § 11-1-3) 
Sec. 19-43. - Nonliability of city regarding water turn-on. 
    The city will not be liable for any damages arising after water is turned on and faucets are on in the house and not turned off. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 1.14, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-2-86, § 2, 2-3-86; Ord. No. O-7A-86, § 2, 7-7-86) 
Sec. 19-44. - Extension of water mains to subdivisions and within subdivisions, or to individuals. 
(a)  Developers of subdivisions or individuals developing single parcels of land shall bear the entire cost for all off-site approach mains and service lines to the property to be developed. 
(b)  All on-site extensions of water service lines to individual lots or lots in a subdivision shall be borne by the developer. 
(c)  The sizes of all water mains and service lines shall be determined by the city. 
(d)  The city may, at its own expense, extend an off-site approach main for the first one hundred (100) feet of the extension to the property to be developed. 
(e)  Where off-site approach mains are required to serve property which has been subdivided or platted for development and resale, the cost of the off-site mains fronting on property not owned by the developer but required and necessary to provide water service to property to be developed shall be borne solely by the developer. The developer will be eligible for reimbursement of the cost of the off-site approach main which fronts on property not owned by him as follows: 
(1)  A charge known as "pro rata," shall be made against each lot or tract of land adjacent to the water main, and the owner thereof, whose water lines will be hereafter connected with any water mains in the city, shall be charged the actual cost for all materials and labor. The pro rata charge shall be based on the frontage of each lot. Where lots or tracts have irregular sizes and shapes, pro rata charges shall be based upon average frontage of such lots. (Average frontage of a lot equals the front lot width and rear lot width divided by two (2).) Where individual residential service connections are made along the alignment of the water main, the same pro rata charge as established above shall be made. 
(2)  Upon approval and acceptance of the system by the city, the city will enter a pro rata reimbursement agreement with the developer which shall include, but not be limited to, engineering data, verification of cost of all materials and labor associated with the line and agreements as to the warranty of the line installed by the developers. 
(3)  The city will refund to the subdivider pro rata charges received from applicants who desire to connect to the off-site mains with the total amount of refund not to exceed the amount of the subdivider's cost of the off-site improvements. 
(4)  In addition to the pro rata charges on off-site approach mains, the applicants who desire to connect to the mains must pay the other connection charges established in this division. 
(5)  The maximum period of time for the pro rata reimbursement to the subdivider for the off-site mains shall not exceed five (5) years. 
(f)  Where the city requires the developer to install a main which has a diameter larger than eight (8) inches to serve areas other than those to be developed by the developer, the city will pay, upon acceptance, and when funds are available, an amount being the difference between the cost of the oversized main and an eight-inch diameter main. 
(g)  The city may extend water mains in streets, alleys, or easements within the city limits in order to permit connections by those persons desiring water services. A pro rata charge may be made against each lot or tract of land adjacent to the water main. The owner whose water lines shall be hereafter connected with any water mains in the city shall be charged the actual cost for all materials and labor. Pro rata charges shall be based on the frontage of each lot. Where lots or tracts have irregular sizes and shapes, pro rata charges shall be based upon average frontage of such lots. In addition to the pro rata charges on water mains, the property owners must pay the connection charges as established herein. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, §§ 1.12, 1.13, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-2-86, § 3, 2-3-86) 
Sec. 19-45. - Temporary water meter turn-off. 
    A five dollar ($5.00) service charge will be assessed on a customer's water account for having meter turned off for a temporary period, as during cold or freezing weather, an out-of-town trip, or while having plumbing work done. No additional service charge will be assessed for turning the meter back on. 
(Ord. No. O-7A-86, § 3, 7-7-86) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. O-7A-86, adopted July 7, 1986, added §§ 19-43 and 19-44 to div. 2. Inasmuch as sections designated as such had previously been included in div. 2, said §§ 19-43 and 19-44 have been redesignated §§ 19-45 and 19-46, respectively, at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 19-46. - Temporary water service. 
(a)  Temporary water service may be given to a customer who already has a water account in good standing with the city water department. Temporary service shall be limited to a maximum of thirty (30) days. No meter deposit will be required on such service, and garbage charges may be waived if the customer does not plan to use the service. The connect charge for temporary service shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00). The customer will be billed based on the current rates for water and sewer set by the city council. 
(b)  The fifteen dollar ($15.00) service charge for turning on new service where a water connection already exists will remain in effect in all cases other than those where temporary service arrangements are made. 
(Ord. No. O-7A-86, § 3, 7-7-86; Ord. No. O-09E-05, § V, 9-6-05) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 19-45. 
Sec. 19-47. - Service agreement. 
    A service agreement must be executed and delivered to the city by each customer prior to providing continuous water service to new construction, on any existing service when the city has reason to believe that cross-connections or other unacceptable plumbing practices exist, to any new location, to renewed service to any existing location and after any material improvement, correction or addition to private plumbing facilities. The service agreement shall contain the language specified in section II of Ordinance No. O-2A-96, incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. O-2A-96, § I, 2-19-96) 
Editor's note- The service agreement referred to in § 19-47 above has not been included within the Code, but may be found within § II of Ord. No. O-2A-96, on file in the office of the city secretary. 
Secs. 19-48-19-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-12-84, §§ 2.01-2.05, adopted Dec. 17, 1984, not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been treated as superseding the provisions of art. III, with the exception of §§ 19-56 and 19-62. Formerly, §§ 19-57-19-61 of art. III pertained to similar subject matter and were derived from: Code 1960, § 11-2-1; Ord. No. O-6C-82, § 2, 6-7-82; Ord. No. O-10-82, §§ 2, 4, 10-4-82; Ord. No. O-4-83, 4-18-83; and Ord. No. O-8-84, §§ 2, 4, 8-23-84. See also §§ 19-14-19-18. 

Sec. 19-56. - Damaging sewage works. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is part of the city sewage works. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. A-71, § 5(A), 10-4-71) 
Sec. 19-57. - Connection to sewer required. 
(a)  All owners or occupants of buildings, or agents for the owners, situated in any section of the city where a sanitary sewer now exists, or where it may hereafter exist, and where the property line of the land on which any such building is situated approaches or extends to within two hundred (200) feet of any such sewer are hereby required to construct or cause to be constructed suitable water closets on their property, and connect the same to the city sewer, under the supervision of the plumbing inspector; provided, however, that where there now exists a septic tank in proper sanitary working condition, it may be permitted to remain in use until such time as it may be found to be unsanitary, and in this event, it may be ordered removed by the plumbing inspector upon ten (10) days' notice to the owner thereof, and all facilities shall be connected to the city sewer within ninety (90) days after service is available. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any such property owners or occupants of such property to keep and maintain the water closet and connection therein in satisfactory working condition and free from any obstruction, and it shall be unlawful for any person to build or use any privy vault above or below the ground in the city or on any lot or parcel of land. All persons now having such privies in such locations are hereby required to abate the same within thirty (30) days after notice by the plumbing inspector to do so and to construct and install water closets and connect the same to the city sewer. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 2.01, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 19-58. - Sewer rates. 
    The monthly rates or charges for services furnished by the sanitary sewer system of the city inside the city limits shall be as follows: 
(1)  The rates for residential customers shall be twenty-four dollars and sixty-seven cents ($24.67) minimum for the first two thousand (2,000) gallons of usage and two dollars and forty-two cents ($2.42) per one thousand (1,000) gallons for anything above two thousand (2,000) gallons, up to a maximum of twenty thousand (20,000) gallons. There will be no charge for residential usage over twenty thousand (20,000) gallons. 
(2)  The rates for commercial customers shall be thirty-four dollars and seventy-one cents ($34.71) minimum for the first two thousand (2,000) gallons of usage and two dollars and forty-two cents ($2.42) per one thousand (1,000) gallons for anything above two thousand (2,000) gallons. There will be no ceiling on commercial sanitary usage charges. 
(3)  Each commercial customer and each residential customer shall be charged one dollar and six cents ($1.06) per month, per meter, for a sewer meter fee. 
(Ord. No. O-12-84, § 2.02, 12-17-84; Ord. No. O-2A-89, arts. I, II, 2-20-89; Ord. No. O-09E-05, § VI, 9-6-05; Ord. No. O-09C-07, § III, 9-4-07; Ord. No. O-09C-08, § II, 9-2-08; Ord. No. O-09B-13, § II, 9-9-13; Ord. No. O-08C-14, § II, 8-18-14; Ord. No. O-09B-15, § I, 9-21-15; Ord. No. O-08C-16 , § II, 8-15-16)

(a)  The tapping fees for connection to the sanitary sewer system shall be as follows:
